The return of the Italian traders brought a return to prosperity that lasted until wars in Italy in the early sixteenth century greatly diminished the number of ships coming from Florence, Genoa, and Venice. The sixteenth century also brought improvements to navigation on the Thames and when London-based merchants stopped shipping through Southampton, London replaced Southampton as the dominant port for trade with the Continent.Platt, Medieval Southampton, pp 109‚Äì30, 147‚Äì50, 152‚Äì4; Alwyn Ruddock, ‚ÄòLondon Capitalists and the Decline of Southampton in the Early Tudor Period,' Economic History Review 2.2 (1949), 137‚Äì51.

By the reign of Elizabeth Southampton had become merely a regional port that connected Hampshire, Sussex, and Dorset with continental ports from the Low Countries to Spain. The town‚Äôs efforts to reverse this decline consisted mainly of trying to convince the national government to grant Southampton monopolies on specific commodities. The town succeeded in gaining protection for the sweet wine trade but such limited remedies could not arrest the general shift of commerce elsewhere.A.L. Merson, ‚ÄòElizabethan Southampton,' Collected Essays on Southampton, J.B. Morgan and Philip Peberdy (eds) (Southampton, 1958), 58‚Äì61, 64. In 1565, of Hampshire kersey cloths exported, only 2,794 went through Southampton, while 19,432 were exported through London.Adrienne Rosen, ‚ÄòWinchester in Transition, 1580‚Äì1700,' Country Towns in Pre-Industrial England, Peter Clark (ed), Themes in Urban History (Leicester and New York, 1981), 149. By 1588 Southampton‚Äôs port had declined to the point that the town could not afford to provide a single ship to participate in the defence against the Spanish Armada.Bettey, Wessex from AD 1000, pp 143‚Äì4. A brief burst of prosperity came in the 1590s, as Southampton served as a base for the privateering encouraged by the war with Spain.Platt, Medieval Southampton, p 222; A.L. Merson, ‚ÄòElizabethan Southampton,' Collected Essays on Southampton, J.B. Morgan and Philip Peberdy (eds) (Southampton, 1958), 60‚Äì1. By 1600, however, Southampton had slipped to eighth in the list of ports according to the amount of customs revenue generated from each, behind London, Hull, Exeter, Bristol, Newcastle, Plymouth, and even Lyme Regis.John Patten, English Towns 1500‚Äì1700, Studies in Historical Geography (Folkestone, Kent, and Hamden, CT, 1978), 230.

Like most towns, Southampton suffered in the late sixteenth century from the combination of nationwide inflation and an increase in civic expenditure as the town government‚Äôs administrative responsibilities grew. Rising population, due to rural poor moving to the towns in search of employment and poor relief, led to social tension, especially during grain shortages: in 1608 people transporting grain out of town were assaulted.Peter Clark and Paul Slack, English Towns in Transition 1500‚Äì1700 (London, Oxford, and New York, 1976), 90. The civic leaders were under pressure both to provide for the poor and also to try to prevent more from coming into the town.James, Third Book of Remembrance, pp xxii‚Äìxxiii. Although those leaders were conscious of the town‚Äôs decline from its earlier glory, Southampton in fact managed to adjust rather well to its new circumstances as a regional trading centre.Platt, Medieval Southampton, pp 221‚Äì2. Southampton had not previously had a cloth industry, but weaving and other cloth-making work expanded rapidly after the arrival of the Walloon refugees in 1567, who brought skill in the making of serges that was new to England.A.L. Merson, ‚ÄòElizabethan Southampton,' Collected Essays on Southampton, J.B. Morgan and Philip Peberdy (eds) (Southampton, 1958), 62. By the early years of the seventeenth century Southampton was using 10,000 tods of wool per year, more than tripling the 3,000 used by Winchester.Adrienne Rosen, ‚ÄòWinchester in Transition, 1580‚Äì1700,' Country Towns in Pre-Industrial England, Peter Clark (ed), Themes in Urban History (Leicester and New York, 1981), 149.

div.head: Population
div.p: Southampton‚Äôs population was relatively small given the port‚Äôs economic significance. The Domesday Book indicates that seventy-six heads of families resided in the town before the coming of the Normans, while another ninety-six had settled in Southampton since the Conquest, thirty-one of them English but another sixty-five from France; the total population likely numbered 650‚Äì850 at the end of the eleventh century. J.B. Morgan, 'Southampton from the Norman Conquest to 1300,' Collected Essays on Southampton, J.B. Morgan and Philip Peberdy (eds) (Southampton, 1958), 24; James, Third Book of Remembrance, p xviii. By the time of the 1334 lay subsidy the population had increased to 2,500, ranking Southampton eighteenth in population among English towns, just behind Winchester. Southampton‚Äôs tax quota was 1,022 shillings, against 1,030 for Winchester, 1,500 for Salisbury, ninth in the country, and 4,400 for Bristol, highest outside London. W.G. Hoskins, Local History in England, 3rd ed (London and New York, 1984), 277). The number of Southampton‚Äôs taxpayers who were assessed in 1332 on goods worth between ¬£10 and ¬£40 (fourteen per cent) indicates that the few leading merchants made a great deal from trade, though the majority of the inhabitants were employed as porters, carters, and other supporting labour who did not earn enough to show up in even the lowest tax bracket.Keene and Rumble, Medieval Winchester, vol 1, pt 1, p 414.

The Black Death shrank the population by a third, as the poll tax of 1377 indicates Southampton had only about 1,600 adults. The 1454 terrier shows some recovery in population to between 1,800 and 2,000, living in some 360 houses within the walls.Platt, Medieval Southampton, pp 262‚Äì3; Keene and Rumble, Medieval Winchester, vol 1, pt 1, p 92. Southampton‚Äôs population then remained static, or even decreased slightly, while other towns grew, dropping Southampton‚Äôs rank to twenty-third in the 1523‚Äì4 lay subsidy, with a payment of ¬£224 against Salisbury‚Äôs ¬£852 (sixth) and Norwich‚Äôs ¬£1,704 (first).W.G. Hoskins, Local History in England, 3rd ed (London and New York, 1984), 278‚Äì9. Still Southampton had surpassed Winchester in wealth, contributing ¬£101 to the 1524 subsidy compared to Winchester‚Äôs ¬£85, though Winchester remained more populous with 595 taxpayers to Southampton‚Äôs 372. A small group of the wealthiest continued to hold a large fraction of the town‚Äôs total wealth, eight burgesses being assessed on wealth exceeding ¬£60, one of those at ¬£250.Keene and Rumble, Medieval Winchester, vol 1, pt 1, pp 92, 415.

Like most urban centres, Southampton saw a substantial increase in population in the late sixteenth century, despite demographic disasters like plague in 1583 and poor harvests in the 1590s. James, Third Book of Remembrance, p xix. A head count for the 1596 muster in the burgess admission book gives a total population of 4,200, of whom 3,270 lived inside the walls, 930 outside. Seven hundred and eighty-four of these were counted as able-bodied men, 297 of them ‚Äòaliens and their families.'L.A. Burgess, 'Southampton in the Seventeenth Century,' Collected Essays on Southampton, J.B. Morgan and Philip Peberdy (eds) (Southampton, 1958), 69. The seventeenth century, however, saw a reversal: plague in 1604 killed at least fifteen per cent of the population and by the 1660s Southampton had dropped to thirty-ninth among English towns with an estimated population of only 3,000. The 1662 hearth tax showed Southampton with only 1,500 hearths taxed compared to Salisbury‚Äô 3,498 (fourteenth in the country) and Norwich‚Äôs 7,302 (first). James, Third Book of Remembrance, p xix; W.G. Hoskins, Local History in England, 3rd ed (London and New York, 1984), 278‚Äì9).

div.head: Government
div.p: For more than a century after the Conquest Southampton was effectively a royal borough but it began to gain some freedom from the control of the king and his sheriff through a charter from King John in 1199.J.B. Morgan, 'Southampton from the Norman Conquest to 1300,' Collected Essays on Southampton, J.B. Morgan and Philip Peberdy (eds) (Southampton, 1958), 29; Platt, Medieval Southampton, p 12. The main governance of the town then came from the guild merchant, which provided civil protections as well as regulating trade.Platt, Medieval Southampton, pp 17‚Äì18. Self-government took a big step in the fifteenth century through a succession of royal charters, and the mayor and council replaced the guild officials as the leading administrators of the town. Henry IV extended the judicial powers of the mayor and bailiffs in 1401 and in 1445 Henry VI gave Southampton one of the first incorporation charters in the country. The independence gained from that charter was increased two years later when Southampton was made a county in its own right, distinct from Hampshire (from what had been known as the ‚Äòcounty of Southampton‚Äô), thereby freeing the burgesses from interference by county officials.Platt, Medieval Southampton, pp 165‚Äì7. The civic leadership was somewhat unstable, because once a family had become wealthy through trade they tended to buy land, usually outside the town, and turn from entrepreneurs to landed proprietors.Platt, Medieval Southampton, pp 62‚Äì3. By the late sixteenth century real power was concentrated in a relatively small subset of the burgesses (approximately fifteen), led by the mayor and ex-mayors. The town‚Äôs efforts to lobby the national government to protect its trade involved seeking patronage through awarding ‚Äòhonorary burgesships‚Äô and positions such as recorder, MP, and even mayor to influential members of the county‚Äôs landed families, including the Paulets, Lamberts, and Wallops.A.L. Merson, ‚ÄòElizabethan Southampton,' Collected Essays on Southampton, J.B. Morgan and Philip Peberdy (eds) (Southampton, 1958), 63‚Äì7.

div.head: Religious History
div.p: A church existed at Hamwic during the Saxon period and St Mary‚Äôs on the same site became the mother church of Southampton, despite lying outside the city walls.M.R. Maitland Muller, 'Southampton before the Norman Conquest,' Collected Essays on Southampton, J.B. Morgan and Philip Peberdy (eds) (Southampton, 1958), 20. After the Conquest dependent chapels were established within the walled town, only later becoming the five independent parishes: St John‚Äôs, St Michael‚Äôs, Holy Rood, St Lawrence‚Äôs, and All Saints.J.B. Morgan, 'Southampton from the Norman Conquest to 1300,' Collected Essays on Southampton, J.B. Morgan and Philip Peberdy (eds) (Southampton, 1958), 33; Platt, Medieval Southampton, p 24. The townspeople were still going in procession to St Mary‚Äôs at the feasts of the Ascension and the Assumption in the thirteenth century.According to a 1225 agreement between the rector of St Mary's and the Priory of St Denys (Blake, Priory of St Denys, vol 2, pp 168‚Äì9). The first monastic institution in the Southampton area was St Denys', an Augustinian priory two miles northeast of town, founded by Henry I in 1127.J.B. Morgan, 'Southampton from the Norman Conquest to 1300,' Collected Essays on Southampton, J.B. Morgan and Philip Peberdy (eds) (Southampton, 1958), 34‚Äì5. The leper hospital of St Mary Magdalene was founded in 1173 north of the town walls, and the more important hospital of St Julian, also known as God‚Äôs House, was founded in 1185 at the southeastern corner of the town to care for the old, poor, and infirm. Many leading burgesses were benefactors of God‚Äôs House in the thirteenth century, when they also supported the Friary, established in 1233‚Äì4, providing the friars with stone buildings in the middle of the town. The fifteenth century brought a change in the religious practices of the wealthy burgesses, who began instead to direct their gifts to their own parishes and to endowing priests who would say prayers for their souls in perpetuity. In consequence, both St Denys' and God‚Äôs House had declined appreciably by the Dissolution, although God‚Äôs House survived as an almshouse.J.B. Morgan, 'Southampton from the Norman Conquest to 1300,' Collected Essays on Southampton, J.B. Morgan and Philip Peberdy (eds) (Southampton, 1958), 36‚Äì7; Platt, Medieval Southampton, pp 25‚Äì6, 64‚Äì5, 205‚Äì6.

Southampton appears to have been more receptive to Protestantism than the rest of the county, though the records tell us surprisingly little about the religious atmosphere in Southampton in the sixteenth century.A.L. Merson, ‚ÄòElizabethan Southampton,' Collected Essays on Southampton, J.B. Morgan and Philip Peberdy (eds) (Southampton, 1958), 67. A conservative burgess complained that attacks on the pope were preached almost daily in Southampton in 1534 and in 1548 Protector Somerset had to forbid a Protestant preacher named Thomas Hancock from preaching in Southampton, for fear of weakening the nation‚Äôs defences: 'My lord said unto me that Hampton was a haven town, and that if I should teach such doctrine as I taught at Sarum the town would be divided, and so should be a way or a gap for the enemy to come in.'Robert Whiting, Local Responses to the English Reformation (Basingstoke, Hants, London, and New York, 1998), 169; D.M. Palliser, 'Popular Reactions to the Reformation during the Years of Uncertainty 1530‚Äì70,' The English Reformation Revised, Christopher Haigh (ed) (Cambridge and London, 1987), 106. In 1567 Southampton was chosen as one of the towns where Protestant Walloons fleeing persecution in the Netherlands could be resettled.Peter Clark and Paul Slack, English Towns in Transition 1500‚Äì1700 (London, Oxford, and New York, 1976), 93; Great Britain, Mary Anne Everett Green (ed), title>Calendar of State Papers, Domestic Series, of the Reign of Elizabeth, Addenda, 1566‚Äì1579 (London, Oxford, Edinburgh, and Dublin, 1871), 32. In the Civil War, Southampton supported parliament and a parliamentary garrison was established there in 1642.Bettey, Wessex from AD 1000, p 182.

div.head: Other Towns
div.p: Of the other towns with surviving dramatic records perhaps the most important is Andover, situated approximately eighteen miles northwest of Winchester in the Test Valley. The river that runs through Andover is the Anton, which joins the Test a few miles south of the town. Andover‚Äôs importance came largely from its position on the main road from London through Salisbury to the west, an old Roman road that intersected at Andover with another old Roman road running from Winchester northwest to Cirencester.VCH: Hampshire, vol 4, pp 345‚Äì58, British History Online, https://www.british-history.ac.uk/vch/hants/vol4/pp345-358 [accessed 3 May 2019]. Andover also was a local centre for the wool trade, much of that wool distributed through the fair at nearby Weyhill. Andover thus ranked fourth in wealth among Hampshire towns in the 1334 subsidy, trailing only Winchester, Southampton, and Ringwood. By the time of the 1524 subsidy Andover still ranked fifth in number of taxpayers but had fallen to tenth in wealth. Derek Keene explains that Andover‚Äôs earlier prosperity had left it with a population its economy could no longer support.Keene and Rumble, Medieval Winchester, vol 1, pt 1, pp 91, 93. The parish, manor, and borough of Andover are all three co-extensive. The manor was a royal vill at the Conquest and in 1175 Henry II granted the town a guild merchant. King John confirmed and enlarged the borough‚Äôs freedoms in a series of charters that were reaffirmed by succeeding monarchs until Elizabeth granted a new charter in 1599. The borough‚Äôs main officials were a bailiff, steward, two chamberlains, and the twenty-four aldermen, known as ‚Äòforwardmen‚Äô in Andover. The burgesses held the manor from the king, with the bailiff effectively acting as lord of the manor. At the time of the Elizabethan charter the guild merchant was replaced by three companies ‚Äì the Leathermen, Haberdashers, and Drapers. Cloth-making was Andover‚Äôs principal industry and members of other trades were required to belong to one of those three companies.VCH: Hampshire, vol 4, pp 345‚Äì58, British History Online, https://www.british-history.ac.uk/vch/hants/vol4/pp345-358 [accessed 3 May 2019]; Barbara Carpenter Turner, A History of Hampshire, The Darwen County History Series, 2nd ed (London and Chichester, 1978), 44.

Portsmouth was founded in 1194 by Richard I as a port for royal ships and in 1256 gained the right to have a guild merchant, but the town‚Äôs growth was partially restrained by Southampton‚Äôs claim that Portsmouth lay within the port of Southampton, and the latter port made continuing efforts to hold onto its position as the major southern port and restrict Portsmouth‚Äôs development. Turner, History of Hampshire, pp 45‚Äì6. Portsmouth thus remained relatively small until the seventeenth century. The English forces sailed from Portsmouth to France before the victory at Crecy in 1346, but Portsmouth was not a walled city and the French burned it in 1338 and successfully attacked again in 1359 and 1377‚Äì80. Henry VII directed that a dry dock be built at Portsmouth in 1495, but the town suffered from a 1563 plague and fires in the port area in 1557 and 1576. Portsmouth‚Äôs population dropped to a mere thousand in the late sixteenth century and it contributed little to resistence to the Spanish Armada in 1588. The seventeenth century saw a reversal of this decline, as a royal charter from Queen Elizabeth in 1600 gave Portsmouth corporate borough status clearly for the first time, although the charter also established that the town could not infringe on the power of the naval captain of the port.Bettey, Wessex from AD 1000, pp 113, 144; Barbara Carpenter Turner, A History of Hampshire, The Darwen County History Series, 2nd ed (London and Chichester, 1978), 72. The dockyard and military base were enlarged and royal and aristocratic visitors became frequent as Portsmouth served to launch both diplomatic and military ventures in the 1620s. The population increased by over 400 per cent in the seventeenth century, so that by the Restoration Portsmouth had become the most populous town in the county.Bettey, Wessex from AD 1000, p 144.

Newport is the principal borough on the Isle of Wight, located just north of the centre point of the island at the head of the River Medina‚Äôs estuary. The town claims borough status from the twelfth century and received its most important charters from Henry VII in 1490 and James I in 1608. Now the county town of the Isle of Wight, the manor of Newport was held by the Crown but administered by the successive lords of the island, in the early seventeenth century, Sir John Oglander. The church was dedicated to St Thomas of Canterbury. The royal forest of Parkhurst lies just to the northwest of Newport.VCH: Hampshire, vol 5, pp 253‚Äì65, British History Online, https://www.british-history.ac.uk/vch/hants/vol5/pp253-265 [accessed 3 May 2019].

Bramley is a village situated about five miles north of Basingstoke, close to the Berkshire border. The manor of Bramley came into the possession of the Paulet family in 1428, and continued to be owned by the lords of the manor of Basing until John Paulet, fifth marquess of Winchester, sold it to Edward Pitt in 1642. The church of St James dates mainly from the twelfth century, though the existing brick tower replaced a wooden one only in 1636.VCH: Hampshire, vol 4, pp 140‚Äì5, British History Online, https://www.british-history.ac.uk/vch/hants/vol4 [accessed 3 May 2019]. Bramley purchased the Book of Homilies shortly after its publication in 1547, one of the first parishes to do so, yet it was one of the last to exchange its Catholic chalice for an Anglican communion cup.Ronald Hutton, ‚ÄòThe Local Impact of the Tudor Reformation,' The English Reformation Revised, Christopher Haigh (ed) (Cambridge, 1987), 124 n 46; Christopher Haigh, English Reformations: Religion, Politics, and Society under the Tudors (Oxford, 1993), 247.

Weyhill is located two and half miles west of Andover, near the Wiltshire border. The parish church is dedicated to St Michael; most of the fabric is modern. The village‚Äôs main claim to fame is the Weyhill Fair, held on a hill west of the village for six days in late September or early October. Hardy claims to have used the Weyhill fair as the model for the fair at which the mayor of Casterbridge sells his wife, and in fact the fair‚Äôs literary notoriety goes all the way back to a mention in Piers Plowman. In 1554 Princess Elizabeth intervened on behalf of Weyhill when one of many efforts was made to move the fair to Andover.Weyhill Fair was originally held 28‚Äì30 September, then over 6 days from 8‚Äì13 October, and then moved to the 10th (VCH: Hampshire, vol 4, pp 394‚Äì9, British History Online, https://www.british-history.ac.uk/vch/hants/vol4/pp394-399 [accessed 3 May 2019]).

The church and village of Wootton St Lawrence are located about three miles west of the centre of Basingstoke, most of the parish lying to the west of the church. The land in the parish was nearly all owned by the monks of St Swithun‚Äôs Priory, Winchester, until the Dissolution, when possession passed to the dean and chapter of Winchester Cathedral. The Wither family held the lease of the manor of Wootton, usually known as ‚ÄòManydown,' at least as early as the fifteenth century and eventually purchased the land from the dean and chapter in 1649. The Kingsmill family of Sydmonton Court in Kingsclere parish, a few miles north of Wootton, leased Fabians manor. Another family of local importance were the Ayliffes, who leased a property called Skeyers Farm from Magdalen College. The church was entirely rebuilt in the 1860s, except for the tower, which is fourteenth century.VCH: Hampshire, vol 4, pp 239‚Äì42, British History Online, https://www.british-history.ac.uk/vch/hants/vol4/pp239-242 [accessed 3 May 2019]. The rector of St Lawrence in the early seventeenth century was Charles Butler (1560‚Äì1647), perhaps best known as the author of a book on bees, The Feminine Monarchie (1609), as well as works on logic, on music theory, and on the regularizing of English spelling. Butler was the master of Holy Ghost School in Basingstoke for five years before coming to Wootton St Lawrence in 1600 and served there until his death.

div.head: Schools
div.p: Winchester College, the oldest major public school in England, was founded in 1382 by William of Wykeham, bishop of Winchester from 1367 to 1404.This history of Winchester College is adapted (with permission) by Cowling from her ‚ÄòPerformance at Winchester College,' pp 101‚Äì115. It was the first endowment of its kind, intended as a feeder school for his earlier foundation of New College, Oxford, in 1379. At the time it was probably the largest and best endowed school in Europe. Henry VI was later to copy this pattern of integrating school and college when he founded Eton College in 1443 as a feeder school for King‚Äôs College, Cambridge. The college buildings lie just south of the cathedral precinct at the southeast corner of the city.

The original foundation of Winchester College consisted of the warden, ten fellows (who took on duties such as the sub-warden, the sacristan, and the bursar, in rotation), the headmaster, the usher (the only other master until 1650), three chaplains, three lay clerks, sixteen quiristers (choristers), and seventy scholars ('pauperes et indigentes'), whose education was free. There were to be no more than ten commoners, that is, those whose fathers paid for their education, but by the end of the sixteenth century the numbers of commoners had increased considerably and included day boys from Winchester after the demise of Winchester‚Äôs grammar school at the Reformation. Other boys who could claim direct descent from Wykeham, referred to as Founder‚Äôs Kin, swelled the intake, even though their conditions of entry were less stringent than those of the other scholars. Although there was often little substance in such claims of family ties to Wykeham and the process was much abused, the privilege was not abolished until the late nineteenth century. The provision for seventy scholars remains to the present day.

Thanks to the prescience of the draftsman of the 1400 Founder‚Äôs Statutes and scrupulous adherence to the provisions in Rubric 41: De Libris Conservandis et non Alienandis ('books to be kept and not parted with'), the records of the college are well preserved and in the case of the bursars' accounts, almost complete.Kirby, Annals of Winchester College, p 517. These records attest to the varied dramatic and paradramatic activities enjoyed by the scholars from the college‚Äôs founding in the late fourteenth century until the Interregnum. These activities included both the visits of professional entertainers and the boys‚Äô own performances that ranged from the ceremony of the boy bishop to plays by Plautus and Terence.

Winchester also had a grammar school attached to the cathedral, but it disappeared at the Reformation and there are no surviving records that might tell of dramatic activity there. Basingstoke‚Äôs Holy Ghost School was first mentioned in 1548 and may have been founded as early as 1524, and Andover is known to have had a school from 1569.VCH: Hampshire, vol 2, pp 368‚Äì71; VCH: Hampshire,vol 4, pp 345‚Äì58, British History Online http://www.british-history.ac.uk/vch/hants/vol4/pp345-358 [accessed 27 July 2019]. However, the only other Hampshire school known to have engaged in drama was Southampton‚Äôs Free Grammar School. It was founded in 1553 by the mayor and council, who served as its governors, and was located in Winkle Street near the Watergate.Butler, Book of Fines, vol 2, p xxi.

div.head: Oglander of Newport (Isle of Wight) and Portsmouth
div.p: Sir John Oglander (1585‚Äì1655) was a member of a family that long had lived on the Isle of Wight. He was the son of Sir William Oglander of Nunwell, Isle of Wight, and Ann n√©e Dillington of Knighton, Isle of Wight. He studied at Winchester College, Balliol College, Oxford, and Middle Temple, and succeeded to his father‚Äôs estates in 1609. Knighted in 1615, Oglander became deputy governor of Portsmouth in 1620, but gave up that position and instead was appointed deputy governor of the Isle of Wight in 1624. He represented Yarmouth, Isle of Wight, in parliament in 1625, 1626, and 1628, and was sheriff of Hampshire from 1637 to 1639. Oglander supported the king during the Civil War, particularly when Charles retreated to Carisbrooke Castle on the island. Oglander lived at Nunwell House, which still stands, near Brading at the eastern end of the island.

Oglander‚Äôs journal, commonplace book, and accounts provide a detailed picture of his own life and that around him on the Isle of Wight. His nineteenth-century editor, W.H. Long, likens Oglander to John Aubrey, remarking that Oglander 'was a lover of gossip, and recorded for the information and amusement of posterity any particulars that struck his fancy, whether trivial or important.' Still, Long says, ‚ÄòOf everything that came under his notice personally, his account is thoroughly reliable, and his details of contemporary matters and incidents maybe safely accepted as trustworthy.' His dating can be suspect, however, and 'his statements of events which occurred before his time will not always bear strict examination.'W.H. Long, 'Introduction,' The Oglander Memoirs: Extracts from the MSS. of Sir J. Oglander, Kt., of Nunwell, Isle of Wight, Deputy-Governor of Portsmouth, and Deputy-Lieutenant of the Isle of Wight, 1595‚Äì1648 (London, Portsmouth and Isle of Wight, 1888), xxviii‚Äìxxix.

div.head: Paulet-Jervoise of Herriard and Freefolk
div.p: Sir Richard Paulet was born around 1558, the grandson of another Richard Paulet, younger brother of the William Paulet who was the first marquess of Winchester and lord treasurer to three Tudor monarchs. Richard Paulet‚Äôs stature initially rested on the estates his grandfather and father had acquired through marriage. Herriard, valued at ¬£200 per annum, came from his grandmother, Elizabeth Cowdrey. Freefolk, valued at another ¬£180, from his mother, Catherine Andrews.HRO: 44M69 F2/11/30; C.R. Davey (ed), The Hampshire Lay Subsidy Rolls, 1586, with the City of Winchester Assessment of a Fifteenth and a Tenth, 1585, Hampshire Record Series 4 (Southampton, 1981), 3, 53. His own marriage in 1587 to Anne Wallop brought no substantial new estates, but did ally him with his father-in-law, Sir Henry Wallop, long a leader of the Protestant gentry in the county. By the time of his marriage Paulet had served as sheriff of Hampshire in 1583‚Äì4, as receiver for debts in Hampshire, Wiltshire, and Gloucestershire in 1585, and as high collector for his part of Hampshire for the 1586 lay subsidy. In 1590‚Äì1 he was sheriff again and attended on the queen when her progress came to his father-in-law‚Äôs estate at Farleigh Wallop. A year later he was knighted and made a justice of the peace, and he was heavily involved in the militia for the following decade.Lindquist, 'Sir Richard Paulet,' p vii.

A 1593 letter to Lord Burghley seeking the office of captain of Portsmouth offers clear evidence of Paulet‚Äôs ambition. Since Burghley‚Äôs granddaughter had recently married the latest marquess of Winchester, Paulet obviously hoped to trade on family connections, but Burghley disappointed him.Lindquist, 'Sir Richard Paulet,' pp vii‚Äìviii; HRO: 44M69 F2/11/59, F2/12/2. However, this setback only temporarily slowed Paulet‚Äôs steady accretion of lands and offices that led eventually to parliament. Paulet‚Äôs estates and influence were located mainly in the northern half of the county, but he was also made a burgess of Southampton in 1600, when his cousin Thomas Lambert was mayor of the town. Lambert‚Äôs and Paulet‚Äôs mothers were sisters, both daughters of Richard Andrews of Laverstoke. Lambert too was knighted and served as an MP, and the two men engaged in several business and land ventures together. In 1601 Paulet added extensively to the scope of his estates by purchasing the wardship of Thomas Jervoise, whose inheritance included lands in Wiltshire, Shropshire, and Nottinghamshire. Jervoise was soon married to Paulet‚Äôs eldest daughter, Lucy, and as Paulet had no son he adopted his new son-in-law as his heir. In 1604 Paulet was elected to James I‚Äôs first parliament as member for Whitchurch and he served again in 1610, keeping a diary that provides many details of that parliament‚Äôs debate over the 'Great Contract' that Robert Cecil aimed to forge between parliament and the king. Paulet made his first and only speech in the House of Commons in the brief 'Addled' parliament of 1614. Paulet died shortly thereafter and was buried in St Nicholas, Freefolk, where his monument dominates the small church.Lindquist, 'Sir Richard Paulet,' pp vii‚Äìviii.
Paulet was a great reader. In December 1596 he wrote this memorandum:

quote.p: ‚ÄòIn what sort I layde my bookes into my chest in the Closet vz On the left hand of the chest beying opening I layd and Packt all the bookes I had of Mr Puttenham, which reached halfe way the Chest

At the right hand at the verye end I layd & Packt Certeyne bookes of dyvynytie and of Controversies in religion, together with some Lawe bookes: at the hether side next the Locke i packt Certeyne englishe bookes Conteyning histories, Planting surveyghinge and suche like.

At the further side right against them & next Mr puttenhams bookes aforesaie I layde all my Lattyne bookes greeke Grammer dixtionarye and such like. / Most of my Lawe bokes, Statutes Chronycles and sermones bookes Concerning religion and the bookes of Martyrs and such like lye. ether in my Chamber, Buttrye of parler./ Wher god graunt me tyme and grace to peruse them.‚ÄôHRO: 44M69 F5.

div.p: Religion was certainly a great interest of Paulet‚Äôs, though it is not clear which way Paulet leaned or indeed if he had a great commitment to a particular religious position. When preparing to take refuge on the Isle of Wight during an invasion scare in 1599, Paulet noted that he intended to take with him a Bible and ‚ÄòMr Egertons book of the principles of Religion‚Äô (‚ÄòA noat of what Armors I must carye with me to the Isle of Wight‚Äô).HRO: 44M69 G5/20/58. Egerton was a famous Puritan divine, and the book was possibly his translation of a popular French treatise by Matthieu Virel. The 1610 diary of Paulet‚Äôs time in London describes the many sermons he heard at Paul‚Äôs Cross and elsewhere with the same detached lack of comment with which he recorded the speeches in parliament.Lindquist, 'Sir Richard Paulet,' p ix. His will left money for ‚Äòa competent yearly maintenance for a minister who also should be a sufficient preacher to instruct the people in the knowledge of gods word and administer divine service and sacraments in my church or chapel of Freefolk.‚ÄôTNA: PROB 11/127. We thus have no way of knowing whether religion was the main reason for his 1607 purchase of a play he called ‚Äòthe widow of watlingstreet‚Äô ‚Äì that is, the Thomas Middleton play usually known as The Puritan.

Thomas Jervoise was born 11 June 1587, only son of Thomas Jervoise of Britford, Wiltshire, but was orphaned at an early age after which he lived with his stepfather, George Wrottesley. In 1601 the fourteen-year-old Thomas‚Äô wardship was purchased by Sir Richard Paulet; Jervoise then married Paulet‚Äôs daughter Lucy and was made Paulet‚Äôs heir. Jervoise inherited the Herriard and Freefolk estates at Paulet‚Äôs death in 1614 and continued to live in Hampshire, although he often visited the estates in Wiltshire, Worcestershire, and Shropshire inherited from his father, particularly Britford in Wiltshire and Chelmersh in Shropshire.

Jervoise was knighted in 1607 and first elected to parliament in 1621 from Whitchurch, the seat that had been Paulet‚Äôs. During the 1624 session he kept a journal similar to Paulet‚Äôs if somewhat narrower in scope, as it deals only with proceedings in the Commons, and of those primarily the foreign policy debates. Jervoise held the Whitchurch seat through the Civil War, in which he staunchly supported the parliamentary side, including with some ¬£15,000 of his own money. He died on 20 October 1654 and is buried at Herriard. Thomas‚Äô eldest son, Richard, also supported parliament as a captain of the Hampshire militia and was killed in battle in 1645. The next oldest son, Thomas, inherited the Jervoise estates and himself served in parliament in the 1680s.

The Jervoise family still own and live at Herriard Park, four and a half miles south of Basingstoke and set just to the east of the village church, St Mary‚Äôs. The current house was built in the late twentieth century, replacing a house of about 1700. Nothing is known of the earlier house used by Sir Richard Paulet and Sir Thomas Jervoise.'Herriard Park,' Historic England, https://historicengland.org.uk/listing/the-list/list-entry/1000861 Paulet appears to have preferred Freefolk, his manor some fifteen miles west of Herriard on the River Test, a little over a mile east of Whitchurch, which both men served in parliament. St Nicholas', Freefolk, still contains an impressive monument to Paulet, who is buried there. Jervoise also spent more time at Freefolk in the years covered by the records in this collection but settled the manor on his son Richard, and when Richard died in 1643 the Freefolk estate passed to his wife‚Äôs family and was eventually sold. Nothing remains of the manor house of the seventeenth century.VCH: Hampshire, vol 4, pp 282‚Äì5, British History Online, https://www.british-history.ac.uk/vch/hants/vol4/pp282-285 [accessed 3 May 2019].

div.head: Seymour of Elvetham and Netley
div.p: Edward Seymour, earl of Hertford (1539‚Äì1621), was the eldest son of Edward Seymour ‚Äî who was duke of Somerset and lord protector during the reign of Edward VI ‚Äî and his second wife, Anne Stanhope. He lost his title and lands when his father was executed in 1552. Queen Mary restored some of his inheritance, but he did not regain a title until Elizabeth created him earl of Hertford in 1559. The following year he secretly married Katherine Grey, who was required to notify the sovereign of any decision to marry because of her own strong blood claim to the throne. Both Katherine and Edward were imprisoned in the Tower until Katherine‚Äôs death in 1568, when Edward was released and allowed to appear at court. In 1582 he again made a clandestine marriage to Frances Howard that only became publically known a decade later. In 1591 he attempted to gain favour with the queen by entertaining her with elaborate pageantry at Elvetham, but in 1595 he angered her again by petitioning to have his marriage to Katherine Grey proclaimed valid and his sons legitimate. He was again committed to the Tower, but only for two months, and in 1602 he was appointed lord lieutenant of Somerset and Wiltshire. Under King James he served as ambassador to Brussels and continued as lord lieutenant. He was buried in the Seymour Chapel of Salisbury Cathedral.

Hertford‚Äôs principal residence was Tottenham Lodge, at Great Bedwyn, Wiltshire, which Hertford had built in preference to nearby Wulfhall, which he had inherited from his father. He also held the manor of Elvetham, Hampshire, which had been in the Seymour family since the mid-fifteenth century.VCH: Hampshire, vol 4, pp 74‚Äì6, British History Online, https://www.british-history.ac.uk/vch/hants/vol4/pp74-76 [accessed 3 May 2019]. In 1602 Hertford purchased the former Netley Abbey from William Paulet, the fourth marquess of Winchester, and was residing there at his death.

Hertford‚Äôs son, Edward Seymour (1561‚Äì1612), was born in the Tower and declared illegitimate because the queen had invalidated his parents‚Äô clandestine marriage. Several attempts were made to restore his legitimacy and even to have him named Elizabeth‚Äôs successor, but neither Elizabeth nor James would agree. He was usually addressed as 'Lord Beauchamp,' his father‚Äôs lesser title, though he had no legal right to it, and he predeceased his father in 1612.

div.head: Wriothesley of Titchfield
div.p: Thomas Wriothesley was born in 1505 in London, son of William, a herald. He was educated at St Paul‚Äôs School and then Trinity Hall, Cambridge, where he was a student of Stephen Gardiner. He began to serve Thomas Cromwell in 1524 and in 1530 became joint clerk of the signet to Gardiner, who had become the king‚Äôs secretary. Cromwell and the king employed Wriothesley in a variety of matters, many of them concerning the king‚Äôs divorce from Katherine of Aragon. He was also given the job of destroying St Swithun‚Äôs shrine at Winchester Cathedral and seizing all the treasure and relics. In 1539 Thomas Wriothesley was elected to parliament as a knight of the shire for Hampshire. Wriothesley managed to survive Cromwell‚Äôs fall and became increasingly important in national affairs, eventually being named lord chancellor in 1544 and, by King Henry‚Äôs will, earl of Southampton in 1547. He was generally associated with the religious conservatives who moderated the advance of the Reformation as long as Henry VIII was alive, but after Henry‚Äôs death he came into conflict with Somerset, the Lord Protector, who feared Wriothesley might lead a Catholic coup in favour of Princess Mary. He was placed under house arrest at his London residence, Lincoln House in Holborn, became ill and died 30 July 1550.

At the Dissolution the king had recognized Wriothesley‚Äôs service by granting him Titchfield Abbey and Beaulieu Abbey, as well as Quarr Abbey on the Isle of Wight. Wriothesley converted the former Titchfield Abbey buildings into a grand residence, called Place House. The impressive gatehouse with four octagonal turrets still stands, though the rest of the house has been demolished. Wriothesley‚Äôs service to Cromwell and the king meant he himself stayed only infrequently at his new Hampshire house. It was his wife Jane (n√©e Cheney) who celebrated Christmas with plays and masques at Titchfield in 1538.See . Thomas Wriothesley‚Äôs son Henry, the third earl of Southampton, and grandson Henry, the fourth earl, also kept Titchfield as their country residence, though the fourth earl, famous as Shakespeare‚Äôs patron, spent more time in London.

Hampshire offers records of many varieties of dramatic and musical entertainment in venues ranging from monasteries and schools to towns, rural parishes, and private households. From Winchester comes the text traditionally considered the earliest example of drama in Britain, the late tenth-century Quem quaeritis trope performed on Easter morning by the monks of St Swithun‚Äôs Priory. St Swithun‚Äôs also celebrated the feast of the Holy Innocents with a boy bishop from the early fourteenth century until the Dissolution, as did Winchester College.

Winchester College also put on its own plays in the late sixteenth century, attested by accounts of the expenses of constructing the stage and by descriptions in Latin dictations given by one of the masters. A manuscript play performed at the college brought the professional theatre‚Äôs fashion for Senecan revenge tragedy into the academic setting, even appearing to echo some of Marlowe‚Äôs lines, if not his skill.

Hampshire is especially rich in evidence of the activities and routes of itinerant players, minstrels, musicians, jesters, jugglers, dancers, tumblers, and other performers. Southampton, Winchester, and Winchester College have nearly complete sets of accounts from the late fourteenth century to the early seventeenth, augmented by occasional records from monasteries and smaller towns like Andover and Newport (on the Isle of Wight). Many of these records provide details usually lacking in other such records, such as the size of visiting troupes, the exact dates of their visits, and even the names of some performers, as well as unusual combinations such as puppeteers travelling with a bearward. Two of the named playing places still stand: Winchester College Hall and Southampton‚Äôs hall above the Bargate.

Locally produced entertainments include rare evidence of a saint‚Äôs play of St Agnes at Winchester in 1409.See . Records of the seasonal festivity known regionally as a ‚Äòking ale‚Äô range from a late fourteenth-century coroner‚Äôs report of a stabbing during a performance to the details of the feasting and playing at Wootton St Lawrence in the early seventeenth century, decades after such activities had been prohibited by Bishop Cooper.See .

Among entertainments for aristocratic households were those for visiting royalty, such as those provided for the future Edward II by Sir Roger Pedwardyn at South Warnborough in 1302‚Äì3 and the elaborate pageantry the earl of Hertford put on at Elvetham when Queen Elizabeth visited in 1592.See Appendix 2 and . Sir John Oglander‚Äôs chatty notebooks tell us a good deal about the entertainments enjoyed by the aristocracy of the Isle of Wight as well as seasonal festivities on the island that had disappeared by the early seventeenth century. Records of Sir Richard Paulet and his adopted son, Sir Thomas Jervoise, include their activities in London, where they attended plays and court entertainments, and at home in Hampshire, where they rewarded visiting performers from musicians to maskers and a lord of misrule.

div.head: Monastic
div.p: The earliest known dramatic activity in Hampshire took place in the monasteries. The Regularis Concordia, rules for life in Benedictine houses throughout England adopted at the council of Winchester between 965 and 975, contains the Visitatio Sepulchri, including the Quem quaeritis trope, a sung dialogue that was part of the liturgy for matins on Easter morning and is traditionally considered to mark the beginning of medieval drama in Britain. Although there are no records of specific performances of the Visitatio in Hampshire, the Regularis Concordia is thought to be largely the work of √Üthelwold, bishop of Winchester from 963 to 984, and the Visitatio text is also found in the Winchester Troper, a collection of music created at Winchester. The Visitatio Sepulchri was thus almost certainly performed annually from the late tenth century up until the Dissolution by the monks of St Swithun‚Äôs Priory, and probably at Hyde Abbey, Winchester‚Äôs other Benedictine house.Frere, Winchester Troper, p 17; Symons, Regularis Concordia, pp 49‚Äì50. See .

Another practice that brought dramatic elements into the liturgy was the festival of the boy bishop ‚Äì choosing one of the cathedral choir boys to play the role of the bishop on the feast of the Holy Innocents (28 December). The obedientiary accounts of St Swithun‚Äôs Priory record gifts of wine to the boy bishop on Innocents‚Äô Day from 1326-7 right up to the year of the priory‚Äôs dissolution, 1536‚Äì7.See and . The St Swithun‚Äôs accounts consistently use the term 'episcopus iuuenum' ('bishop of the youths') rather than 'episcopus puerorum' ('bishop of the boys'), the phrasing used in the Winchester College records (see , for example). It is unlikely, though, that the St Swithun‚Äôs phrasing means that its participants were older than usual; elsewhere the ceremony is known by several names, including 'episcopus innocentium' and 'episcopus elemosinarie.'Salisbury Cathedral called its boy bishop 'episcopus choristarum.' The many records of boy bishops at Durham Priory refer to the 'episcopus elemosinarie,' 'episcopus puerili,' and even 'episcopus puerili elemosinarie' (see ‚ÄòCounty Durham‚Äô, Records of Early English Drama North-East, http://community.dur.ac.uk/reed.ne/?page_id=10). Chambers mentions the St Swithun‚Äôs accounts of the boy bishop but gives more space to boy bishops at Hyde Abbey and St Mary‚Äôs convent that were probably inventions of Thomas Warton (Medieval Stage, vol 1, p 361; see the appendix on Warton‚Äôs records. See also James Michael John Fletcher, The Boy Bishop at Salisbury and Elsewhere (Salisbury, 1921); and for more recent discussions of the boy bishop, Hutton, Rise and Fall (Oxford, 1994; rpt 2011), 10‚Äì12, 53‚Äì4; and Max Harris, Sacred Folly: A New History of the Feast of Fools (Ithaca and London, 2011), 172‚Äì180. Records of boy bishops can be found in many published REED collections, and records of boy bishops at Salisbury and Durham will appear in forthcoming collections in REED Online. (See School Drama for Winchester College‚Äôs boy bishop ceremonies.)

St Swithun‚Äôs also employed outside performers, mainly musicians, to augment the ceremonies on important feast days like Christmas, Easter, and the feast of the house‚Äôs patron saint, as did St Denys' Priory and Netley Abbey, both near Southampton, and Southwick Priory near Portsmouth (see Travelling Performers). Other Hampshire monastic houses probably enjoyed visiting performers too but no relevant records have survived from houses like the abbeys at Hyde, Mottisfont, and Beaulieu, or the Benedictine convents of Nunnaminster (Winchester), Romsey, and Wherewell.

Several stories about early dramatic and musical activity in Winchester first appeared in Thomas Warton‚Äôs 1774 History of English Poetry and have been repeated in Chambers‚Äô Medieval Stage and other histories of English drama. The records of the boy bishop at Winchester College that Warton included come from extant manuscripts and are thus included with the main records of REED Online‚Äôs Hampshire collection. However, the manuscripts in which Warton claims to have found several of his most interesting stories have not survived ‚Äì or never existed ‚Äì and there is reason to think that the stories may be Warton‚Äôs inventions. These stories thus appear here in an appendix with an explanation of why they are problematic (see Appendix 4).

div.head: Seasonal Festivity
div.p: Churchwardens‚Äô accounts have provided most of the evidence we have of drama at the local, parish level, although like most English counties Hampshire possesses surviving churchwardens‚Äô accounts earlier than 1642 from only a small fraction of its parishes. Among that small fraction some accounts lack details, giving only total receipts and expenses, and others survive only from 1600 or later and thus are very unlikely to contain relevant records. If we restrict our analysis to parishes with pre-1600 accounts we find that six of the eight such parishes yield relevant records.Hutton‚Äôs list of churchwardens‚Äô accounts shows that Hampshire is about average in its number of parishes for pre-1600 churchwardens‚Äô accounts. Hutton lists thirty-one for Devon, but only six for Gloucestershire, three for Bedfordshire, and one for Herefordshire (Rise and Fall, pp 263‚Äì93). The implication is that dramatic activity was quite widespread in the county before the Reformation took hold. Most of the evidence of drama comes from parishes in the northern half of the county, north of Winchester, with only Fordingbridge and Southampton St Lawrence's the exceptions, but we cannot infer much from that pattern as only one other parish in the southern half, Ellingham, has extant accounts, most of them summary. (These figures do not include the Isle of Wight, which is quite literally a place apart when discussing local dramatic activity.)

King ales were the most common form of seasonal festivity in Hampshire, turning up in the records of almost every parish with surviving churchwardens‚Äô accounts earlier than 1600. Andover, Bramley, Crondall, Stoke Charity, Weyhill, Winchester St John‚Äôs, and Wootton St Lawrence all held king ales. Records that mention only summer games (Alton and Newton Valence) or church ales with minstrels and morris dancing (Herriard and South Warnborough) may also concern king ales. A single instance of a similar entertainment occurred at Southampton in 1554‚Äì5, when the mayor sent two men to Wilton to get ‚Äòdisgysinge apparrell ... in the Maye‚Äô and paid for green satin ‚Äòfor the Mayes gowne.'See .

Several parishes (Hartley Wespall, Pamber, Stratfield Saye, Silchester, and Yately) contributed money to, and presumably took part in, king ales in nearby parishes in Hampshire and across the county border in Berkshire (see the king ales at St Laurence's, Reading). The term ‚Äòking ale‚Äô appears to be a regional one: though many counties held ales involving a king or lord figure, the event was called a ‚Äòking ale‚Äô most frequently in Hampshire and the surrounding counties. In addition to Reading, Sherborne (Dorset) called its festivity a ‚Äòking ale,' as did Steyning (Sussex), but the phrase does not turn up in records from Kent, Devon, or Somerset.Rosalind Conklin Hays et al (eds), Dorset / Cornwall, REED (Toronto and Buffalo, 1999), 32‚Äì3, 250‚Äì5; Cameron Lewis (ed), Sussex, REED (Toronto and Buffalo, 2000), 167‚Äì8.

The Hampshire records never explain exactly what a king ale involved, though we can infer that the custom involved at the least choosing a mock king or lord to preside over ale drinking, feasting, and other revelry. A 1580 consistory court case concerning a matrimonial dispute at Newton Valence identified John Smith as ‚Äòsomer lord‚Äô and Clarice Baker as ‚Äòsumer lady of newton.'See . The churchwardens of Wootton St Lawrence paid for the ‚ÄòLadyes Lyueries‚Äô and the ‚ÄòLordes Lyueries‚Äô for an elaborate king ale in 1600.See . Payments to minstrels for contributing to the festivities are common, there are occasional references to morris bells and dancing, and in the 1550s St John‚Äôs Winchester accounts, 11d was paid for ‚Äòpayntynge of the clothe vponn the somerloge.' Hampshire king ales must have resembled the summer game at Wistow, Yorkshire West Riding, where a 1469 court case tells us, 'Iuuuenes ville de Wistow adinuicem habebant prout mos patrie ibidem vnum ludum estiualem vulgariter vocatum Somergame' ('The young people of the town of Wistow, according to a custom of the land, would together hold a summer game, commonly called "Somergame"'). The youth of the parish chose a king and queen who, led by a minstrel, processed to the barn called the ‚ÄòSomerhouse‚Äô where they engaged in plays or games for the rest of the day.Borthwick Institute: CP.F.246, sheet 1; record forthcoming in REED's Yorkshire West Riding collection, edited by C.E. McGee and Sylvia Thomas.

The earliest records of king ales in the county come from Andover, where a coroner‚Äôs report of 1381 describes how a man was killed by falling on another‚Äôs knife during a ‚ÄòKyngespleye.' Andover accounts for a king ale in 1471 reveal that pairs of men and women (‚ÄòRichard Curtes & Philypp Moranttes wiff‚Äô) collected donations to support the parish finances.A similar pattern of men and women collecting in pairs for the king play occur in the records of St Edmund‚Äôs, Salisbury, for the 1460s.Records forthcoming in REED's Wiltshire including Salisbury collection, edited by C.E. McGee, Rosalind Hays, and Audrey Douglas. It is uncertain whether that pattern was common in the region, or perhaps shows up in these two parishes because they were connected by the main road from London that led through Andover to Salisbury and on to Exeter. The king ale records from other parishes come mostly from the sixteenth century, decreasing in number as the Reformation spread across the county. Thomas Cooper, bishop of Winchester, issued a diocesan letter in 1585 that called for an end to ‚ÄòChurch Ales, maygames, morish daunces, and other vaine pastimes ... which they have pretended to be for the relief of their Churches....‚Äô The strongly Protestant Cooper was distressed by the number of those in his diocese who clung to such traditional popish practices, complaining that it ‚Äòis a straunge perswasion among Christians, that they can not by any other meane of contribution repaire their Churches, and set forth the service of God, but that they must first do sacrifice to the Devill, with Dronkennes and dauncing, and other ungodly wantonnes.' Parishes that held king ales were among the most resistant to change: Wootton St Lawrence saw its incumbent removed, Stoke Charity was one of the last churches to obey the 1559 directive to remove side altars, and Bramley did not exchange its Catholic chalice for a Protestant communion cup until 1571.Haigh, English Reformations, p 245. Some parishes may have continued their king ales, hiding what they were up to by recording the receipts only as ‚Äòclere gaines at whytsontide.' Bramley‚Äôs churchwardens did not call their ale a king ale after 1532‚Äì3, but records of Banbury, Oxfordshire, tell us that Bramley‚Äôs players travelled there in 1555‚Äì6.Alexandra F. Johnston, ‚Äò"What Revels are in Hand?": Dramatic Activities Sponsored by the Parishes of the Thames Valley,' English Parish Drama, Alexandra F. Johnston and Wim H√ºsken (eds), Ludus: Medieval and Renaissance Theatre and Drama 1 (Amsterdam and Atlanta, 1996), 101; Oxfordshire History Centre: BOR2/XVII/i/1, f 170v. Wootton St Lawrence engaged in no such subterfuge, however, recording the receipts and expenses for its 1600 king ale in great detail, and it did much the same in 1603, 1605, and 1612. See , , , and . For a more detailed analysis of these king ale records, see Greenfield, ‚ÄòParish Drama,' pp 107‚Äì18, and ‚ÄòCarnivalesque,' pp 19‚Äì28).

Certainly Cooper was right that many parishes relied on king ales as their main source of income. Wootton St Lawrence‚Äôs churchwardens spent the considerable sum of ¬£7 13s 10d on their king ale in 1600, including 23s 10d for minstrels and 8s 6d for the lords‚Äô and ladies‚Äô ‚ÄòLyueries,' but they collected enough money from the participants that the event made a profit of ¬£3 17s 1 1/2d, roughly four times as much as the 19s 4d the parish received in income from all other sources. Ronald Hutton notes that ‚Äòas church ales became rarer, they also tended to be more spectacular when they were held‚Äô and Wootton St Lawrence‚Äôs is his primary example.The Stations of the Sun: A History of the Ritual Year in Britain (Oxford, 1996), 255. However, in Rise and Fall, p 158, he incorrectly asserts of Wootton St Lawrence that ‚Äòafter 1605 it ceased to hold any‚Äô king ales. Many parishes had no other means of meeting their expenses, especially for poor relief and repairs to the church fabric, until they began to impose rates on all the parishioners, typically in the second or third decades of the seventeenth century.

The Isle of Wight had its own form of May game, described both in Newport‚Äôs 'Ligger Book' and in Sir John Oglander's commonplace book. On the first Sunday in May, the young people of Newport went in procession into nearby Parkhurst Forest, accompanied by a minstrel and morris dancers and led by a man called the ‚ÄòVice‚Äô and by a lord appointed by the town bailiffs.See . This custom, connected with the people‚Äôs right to gather wood in the royal forest, lasted as late as 1621.See Cowling, ‚ÄòWood Eaves,' pp 20‚Äì8. The island also had the more usual kind of May celebration, as Oglander tells of Sir John Leigh and his future wife, Elizabeth Dingley, first meeting when they were lord and lady of the maypole.See . Oglander‚Äôs description does not indicate whether these members of the gentry were joining in a festivity of the local folk or engaging in some kind of aristocratic imitation, much as one cannot tell exactly what was happening when the parish churchwardens of Crondall rewarded a minstrel for playing with some morris dancers ‚Äòbefore my lady marques of Exeter‚Äô in 1554‚Äì5.See .

The Christmas season also occasioned festive customs, though Hampshire offers less evidence for that time of year. A 1563 coroner‚Äôs report tells us that one John Hypper of Houghton died after being struck in the testicles while ‚Äòplaynge Christenmas games‚Äô in his house. Lords of misrule commonly appeared at Christmas, such as the one fined by the mayor of Southampton in 1521 for taking geese and a boar in the street and the one rewarded by Sir Richard Paulet in 1600.See and . Neither of these records of lords of misrule is definitely datable to the Christmas season, and it is possible that they were connected to summer games instead. Paulet was also visited by wassailers from villages near his houses at Herriard and Freefolk at Christmas time.

Hocking was another custom common in the county. Records of money collected at Hocktide come from rural parishes like Herriard and South Warnborough and from urban ones like St Lawrence‚Äôs Southampton and St John‚Äôs Winchester. Most of the records date to the middle of the sixteenth century, but at South Warnborough and Alton as late as the 1620s. Hocktide festivities were held on the Monday and Tuesday of the week following Easter week. The most common form of the festivity involved groups of men or women taking ‚Äòprisoner‚Äô individuals of the opposite sex and forcing them to pay a fine to be released. Regional variations appear to have been common, however, as Sir Francis Taverner describes the festivity in his parish of Hexton, Hertfordshire, as involving a contest between the men and women of the parish to pull a pole from the top of a hill to the bottom. The women were always the victors and in fact the women usually end up dominating the men at Hocktide and gathering the largest sum for the parish. The funds thus gathered were given to the parish especially for poor relief but also to pay for repairs to the church fabric and other parish expenses. The Bramley accounts for 1561‚Äì2 are notable in specifying that the hocking money was used to purchase two table cloths and a ‚Äòtreue vessell.' See . Taverner says that at Hexton part of the money gathered was 'then given to the poore, the remaining money the Hockers delivered unto the Churchwardins, who layd out the same in reparation of the church, and Bells and the like‚Äô (BL: Add. MS 6223, f 12v). If Taverner is correct, then in some years all the gatherings from hocking may have been given to the poor directly so that no amount from hocking shows up in the churchwardens‚Äô accounts. See also Sally-Beth MacLean, ‚ÄòHocktide: A Reassessment of a Popular Pre-Reformation Festival,' Festive Drama: Papers from the Sixth Triennial Colloquium of the International Society for the Study of Medieval Theatre, Lancaster, 13‚Äì19 July, 1989, Meg Twycross (ed) (Cambridge, MA, 1996), 233‚Äì41. Taverner resembles Sir John Oglander of the Isle of Wight in writing regretfully in the 1630s or 40s of practices that have disappeared. Taverner sums up his description of Hexton‚Äôs hocking: ‚ÄòI think these nicer tymes of ours, would not only despise these sports, but also account them ymmodest, if not prophane, But those playne and well meaning people did Solace them selves in this manner, and that without offence or Scandall.' BL: Add. MS 6223, f 12v.

div.head: Civic Entertainment: Musicians
div.p: Homegrown dramatic activity in Hampshire appears to have been sponsored almost exclusively by parishes; the towns instead relied on the performances of itinerant troupes. The towns did however employ musicians for a range of entertainment and ceremonial functions. Southampton‚Äôs records provide a great deal of detail about the town's musicians and their relations with the civic government. The first mention of the town musicians, or waits, in Southampton‚Äôs own records comes in the steward‚Äôs accounts for 1433‚Äì4, but the town had employed musicians at least forty years earlier, as Winchester‚Äôs chamberlains gave 18d to three ‚Äòministrallis de Hampton‚Äô in 1394‚Äì5 and Salisbury rewarded Southampton‚Äôs musicians in 1398‚Äì9.See and . Greenfield, 'Using Dramatic Records,' p 81, suggests that the musicians Southampton took on in 1433‚Äì4 were its first town musicians; the 1394‚Äì5 record from Winchester has since come to light. The 1398‚Äì9 record from Salisbury comes from a transcription of the mayor‚Äôs account by Audrey Douglas, forthcoming in REED's Wiltshire including Salisbury collection, edited by C.E. McGee, Rosalind Hays, and Audrey Douglas: ‚ÄòItem iij ministrallis Ville Suthamtonie ij s.‚Äô (Salisbury Corporation Ledger Book A, WSA: G/23/1/1, f 13 (rendered 26 September 1399)). The group mentioned in 1433‚Äì4 may have been adopted by Southampton in that very year. The 1428‚Äì9 accounts do not mention any musicians of the town so the group of the 1390s must have died or moved on. In 1433‚Äì4, though, a rough set of steward‚Äôs accounts includes among expenses for a feast in the guildhall on 13 January a reward of 20d the mayor gave to ‚Äòminstrellis de Wynchester qui modo sunt apud suthampton.' The fair copy of the accounts indicates that on 16 January ‚Äòpredictis minstrellis‚Äô received 6s 8d as their wages for a quarter of the year and Robert Pyle of Salisbury was paid ‚Äòpro vestitu Mynstrellorum de Suthamptonie.' In addition, the steward claimed expenses for going to Winchester on 11 May to go bail for three minstrels named Richard March, John Goddislond, and William Goldfynch. The mayor of Winchester, Walter Hore, had requested that the minstrels be arrested and both they and the steward were questioned by justices at the assizes. A year later Southampton‚Äôs minstrels received both wages and new liveries and the wages were paid to Richard ‚ÄòWayte,' John ‚ÄòWayte,‚Äô and William ‚ÄòWayte.'See . It appears that this group of three musicians played for the mayor and council at the feast in January and were then adopted as the civic waits by Southampton. The fact that they were 'de‚Äô Winchester before they were ‚Äòapud‚Äô Southampton may only mean they came ‚Äòfrom‚Äô Winchester, but their arrest by the mayor of Winchester shortly afterward suggests they were ‚Äòof‚Äô Winchester; that is, they had previously been employed as Winchester‚Äôs waits and that city was not ready to part with them. Southampton went to considerable expense to employ these musicians, paying for liveries as well as wages and protecting them at the assizes, but after a four-year gap in the accounts there is no trace of them in the town‚Äôs records for 1438‚Äì9.

Town musicians then appear infrequently in Southampton‚Äôs records until the early seventeenth century. In 1493 the town paid for liveries for three waits, probably the same ‚Äòministral' ville Southamptonie‚Äô who played at St Denys' Priory, just north of the town, on the saint‚Äôs feast day in that year.See and . Almost a century later there appears to have been only a single musician, as ‚Äòhenrie the Minstrell‚Äô was paid ¬£4 in 1579 for ‚Äòhis ffredome of the keping of the waightes‚Äô and he received his livery for several years. In 1587 the town gave him a poor boy as an apprentice.See . By 1594 there were multiple musicians, as the town gave liveries to ‚Äòweightes.'

In 1607 Southampton increased the size of the town consort, providing liveries for five musicians and also having two ‚ÄòScuttchins‚Äô of silver made for the waits to wear, ‚Äòimpressed with the Townes Armes; Namelye, three Ross [Roses] the lettre H; and the forme of a Tonne.' From that time on the town musicians appear frequently in the records, up to and through the Interregnum. In the 1620s and 1630s, when the town sent players away without allowing them to perform, it regularly gave the musicians new liveries and in 1629 gave them three more silver scutcheons so that all five musicians had such badges.See . The musicians kept the ‚Äòbenevolences‚Äô and other payments they received for performing in a box, from which one of their number stole in 1633.See . The town also placed poor children with them as apprentices and did what it could to help the musicians make a living beyond the official wages it paid, licensing them to keep alehouses and engage in ‚Äòhuckstering‚Äô ‚Äì buying up wares at the market before it opened and reselling them at higher prices.See . All these records give the musicians‚Äô names, allowing us to keep track of the make-up of the consort.

At Winchester unidentified minstrels had been rewarded for playing at the annual dinners of the fraternity of St John as early as 1389‚Äì90,See . but the first definite evidence that the city employed musicians appears in the 1397‚Äì8 chamberlains‚Äô accounts, which include payments for cloth for liveries for ‚Äòministrallis Ciuitatis.' The same year they were paid for getting the ‚ÄòTron,' the city‚Äôs weighing machine that was taken up St Giles‚Äô Hill each year at the time of the annual fair. The city again paid for cloth for its minstrels in 1406‚Äì7, but we only know that they continued for another sixty years from the occasional rewards to entertainers of the city in the records of Winchester College, where they first appear in 1398‚Äì9.See and . The college bursars refer to them variously as ‚Äòministralli,' ‚Äòmimi,' ‚Äòlusores,' and in the 1470‚Äì1 bursars‚Äô accounts, as ‚Äòle Waytys Ciuitatis Wintonie.' It seems probable that the minstrels who performed at the annual dinners of Winchester‚Äôs fraternity of St John were the city‚Äôs own musicians but the fraternity‚Äôs accounts never provide a specific identification. From 1470‚Äì1 to the early seventeenth century no entertainers identified as the city‚Äôs own appear in any of the extant records. Then in 1611‚Äì12 Winchester College rewarded ‚Äòmusicis de Civitate Wintonie,' and similar payments occur in the college accounts every year or two right up to 1642. These musicians first appear in the city‚Äôs own coffer accounts in 1614 and they appear frequently in the records thereafter, including in 1638 when they received new coats. Their leader in 1620 was James Beale, later replaced by someone named Combes by 1633.See , , , and .

The other Hampshire town with many records of musicians is Andover, which has the earliest record of an entertainer in Hampshire. The Domesday Book states that ‚ÄòAdelina joculatrix‚Äô held one virgate of land in Upper Clatford in Andover hundred that was given to her by Earl Roger of Hereford.Domesday indicates that the king was lord of the manor of Upper Clatford, ‚Äòde feudo comitis Rogerij‚Äô; Munby‚Äôs note explains that Earl Roger, son of William Fitz Osbern, had ‚Äòforfeited his lands after the rebellion of 1075' (Julian Munby (ed), Domesday Book, vol 4, Hampshire (Chichester, 1982), section 1, 25). The record is an especially intriguing one since it refers to a female performer. (Another of the rare examples of female performers is the ‚Äòminstrell mayde' who visited Sir Richard Paulet in 1613.) She perhaps had been a performer in Earl Roger‚Äôs household. Munby‚Äôs edition translates ‚Äòjoculatrix‚Äô as ‚ÄòJester‚Äô but the Latin word can mean ‚Äòjuggler‚Äô and perhaps just entertainer in a generic sense ‚Äì thus not distinguishing between juggler, jester, musician, minstrel, actor, or other more specific kind of performer.See the REED Anglo-Latin Wordbook, https://reed.utoronto.ca/wordbook/#I [accessed 12 May 2019].

Most of the evidence of musicians living at Andover comes from wills and inventories of the late sixteenth and early seventeenth century. The 1558 will of William Calley does not specifically identify him as a musician but he had few possessions to leave other than a lute and gittern.See . William Glover, on the other hand, is called a musician and a 1638 inventory shows that he owned books of music as well as instruments.See . This Glover may well have been from a family of musicians, as a musician called ‚ÄòWilliam Glover the elder‚Äô leased two tenements in Charlton, near Andover, from Winchester College in 1593, so the William Glover who died in 1638 may have been his son, William Glover the younger.Himsworth, Winchester College Muniments, vol 2, p 89. Nicholas Fishborne is also identified as a musician of Andover in a 1646 will and inventory.HRO: 1646A/25. Perhaps Fishborne and the Glovers were among the musicians from Andover rewarded by Winchester College in 1629‚Äì30.See . Nothing in the extant records shows whether they served as town musicians like those of Winchester and Southampton. Given Andover‚Äôs location on the main road that led from London to Salisbury and Exeter, musicians there might have found their main occupation in playing for visitors at the town‚Äôs inns, much as the local musicians did at Ware where the town‚Äôs lord high steward protected the livelihoods of resident musicians by restricting ‚Äòforen‚Äô musicians from performing ‚Äòin any Inn or vsuall resortinge place‚Äô for more than a single night.BL: Add. Ms. 27,976, f 109.

Most of the dramatic and musical activity mentioned in the records of Winchester College was provided by visiting entertainers but the boys themselves also performed.For a detailed discussion of the evidence from Winchester College, see Cowling, ‚ÄòPerformance at Winchester College,' pp 101‚Äì15. The records discussed here add a good deal to our understanding of school drama, which has not been studied as extensively as drama at the universities.Motter‚Äôs School Drama in England is still the only book-length study devoted to school drama and it is a general survey that ranges up to the early twentieth century. More recent books that include some treatment of school drama include Lynn Enterline, Shakespeare‚Äôs Schoolroom: Rhetoric, Discipline, Emotion (Philadelphia, 2011), and Elisabeth Dutton and James McBain (eds), Drama and Pedagogy in Medieval and Early Modern England, Swiss Papers in English Language and Literature 31 (T√ºbingen, 2015). Blewitt‚Äôs 1984 survey of the dramatic records of Winchester and Eton uses primary research but ends in 1576; it does not include the records of musicians (who may have ‚Äòplayed‚Äô in a variety of ways) nor the most interesting of the records examined here, those of the scholars‚Äô own performances.‚ÄòDrama at Winchester and Eton,' pp 88‚Äì95, 135‚Äì43.

The earliest form of dramatic activity performed by the scholars themselves appears to have been the celebration of the boy bishop. That celebration was common before the Reformation at cathedrals, including Winchester‚Äôs, at religious houses, and at educational institutions, including New College, Oxford, with which Winchester College was linked by the founder of both, William of Wykeham.At least four other Oxford colleges had boy bishops (John R. Elliot et al (eds), Oxford, vol 2, REED (Toronto and Buffalo, 2004), 612). Winchester College followed St Swithun‚Äôs in staging its boy bishop celebration on the feast of the Holy Innocents, 28 December, unlike Eton, which used St Nicholas‚Äô Day, 6 December. The boy bishop was possibly chosen from among the junior scholars and held office for a single day. Rubric 29 of the Founder‚Äôs Statutes allows for scholars to say or sing vespers, matins, and other divine offices on that day.Kirby, Annals of Winchester College, p 503. An inventory of 1521‚Äì2 includes the cloth-of-gold mitre that William of Wykeham had donated for the use of the boy bishop.See . Other donations for the office were a pastoral staff and the crozier of copper-gilt which was carried before him in procession. The statutes do not describe the exact form of the ceremony but it is likely that Winchester College followed the practice at Salisbury, which William of Wykeham specified in his statutes for New College.John R. Elliot et al (eds), Oxford, vol 1, REED (Toronto and Buffalo, 2004), 12. The Winchester waits, the bishop‚Äôs musicians, and other performers visited the college to join in the ceremonies. In 1405 the boy bishop paid the waits 8d for their performance and in 1412‚Äì13 men of Ropley were paid for dancing and singing in the hall before the scholars' bishop, so it is possible that the boy bishop took up a collection from which he could make such disbursements.See and .

The Reformation brought an end to the boy bishop, but the greatest period of dramatic activity at Winchester College began in 1561 with the arrival of a new schoolmaster, Dr Christopher Johnson. The details of Johnson‚Äôs influence emerge from his dictated lessons, as written down by a scholar named William Badger between 1563 and 1567. These ‚ÄòDictates‚Äô are contained in a small booklet titled Themes at Winchester School (BL: Add. Ms 4379). Of the 422 dictates in Badger‚Äôs notebook, eight have particular significance for drama historians and give us a clear picture of how often and under what conditions plays were acted by the scholars. The plays were mostly in Latin and staged twice a year, at Christmastime and Shrovetide.

In a dictate concerning plays (‚Äòspectacula‚Äô) at Christmas 1563‚Äì4 Johnson refers to characters who appear in Acolastus, a prodigal son play by Dutchman William Fullonius, written in Latin in 1529 (f 20v). During Shrovetide in 1564 the boys acted in a Greek play which ‚Äì according to the wording of the dictate ‚Äì was a rare occurrence (f 27v). The following Christmas (1564‚Äì5) the bursars‚Äô accounts, under ‚ÄòExpenses for buildings and repairs,' record a sum of 11s 6d paid out for expenses regarding the plays in the Christmas holidays.See . In the corresponding dictate, Johnson comments favourably on the boys‚Äô acting styles but his good temper seems not to have lasted, for in the dictate referring to the second of the plays performed at this time he comments somewhat irascibly on the nature of comedies and the difficulties of staging them: ‚ÄòQuid enim aliud est comoedia quam negotiosum nihil?‚Äô ('For what else is comedy than a laborious nothing?') (f 89).

A manuscript tragedy called Pelopidarum Secunda has an epilogue indicating it was performed at Winchester College, probably for the annual Founder‚Äôs Day celebration.See Appendix 3; the editors are grateful to Martin Wiggins for calling their attention to this play. It is number 840 in his British Drama, vol 3, pp 1‚Äì4. Wiggins dates the play to 1590, linking it to the mention of a 'teatro' in the bursar‚Äôs accounts for that year, but there are several other such records in the accounts and Johnson‚Äôs dictates mention plays in years when no stage or theatre was constructed, so any such date must remain conjectural. The play, which is written in English despite the Latin title, tells the well-known story of Agamemnon‚Äôs death and Orestes‚Äô revenge on Clytemnestra and Aegisthus. The play is very long, written in several hands, and has thirty-six speaking parts, making it eminently suitable for school production.

Between 1615 and 1637 a Winchester scholar called Christopher Longland was killed by a sword wound while acting in another tragedy. A poem written by one of his friends and titled 'On ye Death of Longland slaine in acting a Tragedy' hints at the circumstances:

quote.p: Deare heart that was so serious in ye rest! Of all his lyfe, he could not play in Iest! O too too true Tragaedian twas thy task! To practize to be murderd & to maske! A Deadman on ye stage...! See

div.p: Southampton‚Äôs Free Grammar School also staged drama though the records are much less extensive than those of Winchester College. The mayor and council served as the school‚Äôs governors and in 1565‚Äì6 the mayor gave 6s 8d to ‚ÄòMr Leythe Scholemaster for his play.' A decade later the mayor gave 20s to ‚ÄòMr Adrian for his charges and pains in his tragedie,' Adrian (or Hadrian) Saravia having been the school‚Äôs headmaster from 1571 to 1578. The word ‚Äòtragedie‚Äô suggests that the Southampton boys were performing classical works, perhaps in Latin, like their Winchester counterparts. ‚ÄòMr Caliuers playe,' for which the town contributed 16d for paper and candles in 1581‚Äì2, must also have been a school play as ‚ÄòMr Caliuer‚Äô was John Calvert, vicar of St Michael‚Äôs and Saravia‚Äôs successor as schoolmaster.Butler, Book of Fines, vol 2, p xxi; Russell, King Edward VI School, p 350. The records do not indicate whether the mayor actually saw the play performed; if he did, the boys may have performed in the council chamber on the upper floor of the Bargate where itinerant performers entertained the mayor and council, or the mayor may have gone to see the boys at the school itself in Winkle Street near the Watergate.

div.head: Household Entertainment
div.p: The most elaborate entertainments enjoyed by Hampshire‚Äôs aristocratic households occurred when royalty visited the county. Edward I and his son Edward, Prince of Wales, spent the Christmas season of 1302‚Äì3 in Hampshire, the king at Odiham Castle in the northeastern corner of the county and the prince some three miles south at Sir Roger Pedwardyn‚Äôs manor of South Warnborough. The royal wardrobe accounts paid for three clerks from Windsor to come to the court at South Warnborough to perform in an interlude before the future Edward II and for fabric and wire to make costumes to be brought from London (see Appendix 2).

Three centuries later Queen Elizabeth came to the same part of the county on progress in 1591, staying at Odiham before witnessing three days of pageantry at the earl of Hertford‚Äôs nearby residence at Elvetham. The earl had been imprisoned for treason thirty years earlier for secretly marrying Lady Katherine Grey and was still trying to regain the queen‚Äôs favour. His principal residence was Tottenham Hall near Marlborough in Wiltshire but Elizabeth‚Äôs 1591 progress never ventured that far west, so Hertford was forced into extraordinary efforts to make the much smaller manor at Elvetham sufficiently impressive to ‚Äòshew his vnfained loue, and loyal duetie to her most gracious Highnesse.'Davies, ‚ÄòLooking Again at Elvetham,' p 212; records of entertainments in Seymour‚Äôs Wiltshire residences will appear in REED's forthcoming Wiltshire including Salisbury collection, edited by C.
