div.p: Henry Tudor (1457-1509) was Henry VII of England from 22 August 1485. See P&P.
Henry Tudor (1491-1547) was prince of Wales 1502-1509 and Henry VIII of England from 1509. See P&P.

William Blewett (f 7) received wages of 46s 8d for being the sergeant to the mayor for this year (f 8), as well as a gown, hat, and tippet worth 12s 4d (f 9). The king's minstrels here are presumably those of Henry VII and their visit and that of the prince's (the soon- to-be Henry VIII) minstrels must have preceded Henry VII's death on 21 April 1509, since once Henry VIII became king there was no prince.

row.cell:
Item fyrst paid the xxiij day of Iune to the Clerke of the markett by master mayre ys CommandementCostes of the kynges
& quenys seruantes
with other Summa

Item I delyueryd to master mayre to Delyuer vn to the kynges grett mennystrelles by holy Rodys Church Dore & that he delyueryd to them at the ffreyris yatt Summa

div.p: Henry Tudor (1491-1547) was Henry VIII of England from 1509. See P&P.

The queen was in Southampton at this time, as the last entry on f 33 speaks of the mayor's difficulty in discovering where he was supposed to meet the queen. Henry VIII spent a good deal of time in Southampton between 1512 and 1514, involved in preparations for war with France (VCH: Hampshire, vol 5, p 322). Holy Rood Church, now a ruin, is located on the High Street (then called English Street) roughly halfway between the Bargate on the north and the city wall on the south. The 'ffreyris yatt,' that is, the Friar's Gate, was a gate in the town's eastern wall toward its southern end. 'master hussey' probably refers to John Hussey, who was bailiff at this time, rather than Thomas Hussey, who was not made a burgess until 1516‚Äì17 (Butler, Book of Fines, vol 1, pp 74‚Äì5, 177).

trompetteres that Came by water with hym

cell.del: ffor that master stonard mayre payd to a berreward ffor his game

row.cell: Item. ffor that he payd to the bulle bettenges att dyuerse tymes ffyndyng

div.p: Henry Tudor (1491-1547) was Henry VIII of England from 1509. See P&P.

The mayor this year was Peter Stonehard or Stoner, not 'mr holles' (Butler, Book of Fines, vol 1, p 180). The mayor's accounts in the Book of Fines include payments in the same amounts to the king's trumpeters and minstrels (see ), but lack the information about the king coming by water. Nor does the Book of Fines include the payment to the waits of Sarum. The accounts for this year do not include the waits among the officers who received liveries, so the Salisbury waits may have been called upon to provide music for the king and the army. The auditors cancelled the payment to the bearward without explanation.

div.p: Henry Tudor (1491-1547) was Henry VIII of England from 1509. See P&P.
Thomas Grey (1477-1530) was fifth marquess of Dorset from 1501, with residence at Shute House (Devon). See P&P.
Henry Bourchier (1472-1539/40) was fifteenth earl of Essex from 1483, with residence at Gaynes Park (Essex). See P&P.
Richard Grey (1478-1523) was thirteenth earl of Kent from 1503, with residence at Lombard Street (London). See P&P.
Thomas Fitz Alan (1450-1524) was twenty-second earl of Arundel from 1488, with residence at Arundel Castle (Sussex). See P&P.
John de Vere (1499-1526) was fourteenth earl of Oxford from 1512/13, with residence at Hedingham Castle (Essex). See P&P.
Thomas Howard (1443-1524) was seventh duke of Norfolk from 1513/14, with residences at Ashwellthorpe (Norfolk), Sheriff Hutton Castle (Yorkshire) and Framlingham Castle, Suffolk. See P&P.

This year's accounts record a great deal of activity regarding warships; the many entertainers may have come to town with their patrons, who were there for the warships. The king visited the Venetian galleys at Southampton, so the captain of the galleys may have been the Venetian captain rather than an English one. Burch reverses his numbers in giving the folio for the above entries as 34r (Minstrels and Players, p 41).

Many payments this year are for war preparations ‚Äì guns, gunstones, new bulwarks ‚Äì and for 'harnyssynge' of twelve archers sent to the king to do him service in his wars with the French (f 29ff). All the entries are dotted in the left margin.

A number of entries at the bottom of f 59 are related to the queen's visit to the town. It's possible that the entry concerning the king's players at the top of the verso is also connected to the queen's visit, but there was room at the bottom of f 59 to record the players' reward there, so the connection is tenuous.

'Mr dayes' (f 23v) was the house of Nicholas Dey or Daye, mayor of Southampton in 1528‚Äì9. It seems likely that the rewards to Lord Talbot's minstrel and the king's bearward should have been recorded under gifts rather than as presents to Doctor Alyn. Perhaps they were initially not recorded by the scribe, and having left himself no room under gifts, he entered the two rewards to performers immediately above the gifts section of the accounts.

div.p: John Rudstone was Lord Mayor of London in 1528.
Henry Tudor (1491-1547) was Henry VIII of England from 1509. See P&P.
Mary Tudor (1496-1533) was queen of France from 1514. See P&P.
Thomas Wolsey (1475-1530) was cardinal from 1515, with residences at Hampton Court (Middlesex); Bishop‚Äôs Palace, Wells (Somerset); St Bride‚Äôs and York Place (London). See P&P.

Henry Courtenay (1498-1538/9) was nineteenth earl of Devon from 1511 and marquess of Exeter from 1525, with residences at Colcombe Castle, Okehampton Castle, Tiverton Castle and Columbjohn House, Exeter (Devon). See P&P.
Henry Guildford (1489-1532) was comptroller of the king‚Äôs household from 1522, with residences at Leeds Castle (Kent) and London. See P&P.
Ralph Neville (1497/8-1549) was fourth earl of Westmorland from 1498/9, with residence at Brancepeth (Durham). See P&P.

In this year the rewards to performers make up the largest part of the entries and the total amount of 44s 8d. The steward's accounts for this year (SC5/1/36, f 19) include another seven rewards to groups of entertainers, all different from those rewarded by the mayor. 'master Gore' refers to Nicholas Gore or another of the Gore family of Nether Wallop (VCH: Hampshire, vol 4, pp 525‚Äì30, British History Online, http://www.british‚Äìhistory.ac.uk/vch/hants/vol4/pp525‚Äì530 [accessed 24 August 2017]).

div.p: Charles Brandon (1484-1545) was fourth duke of Suffolk from 1513, with residences at Westhorpe Hall (Suffolk), Suffolk Place (Surrey), and Grimsthorpe Castle and Tattershall Castle (Lincolnshire). See P&P.

Edward Guildford (1479-1534) was warden of Kent from 1521, with residences at Halden Manor and Leeds Castle (Kent). See P&P.

The duke of Suffolk may have been a 'good lord to the Towne yn there pursutes' in relation to Southampton's lengthy efforts to gain a 40 mark reduction in the fee farm, which was finally granted by the Crown in 1531 (see Platt, Medieval Southampton, p 219).

div.p: Arthur Plantagenet (1480-1541/2) was sixth viscount Lisle from 1523, with residence at Calais, France. See P&P.
Edward Stanley (1509-1572) was twelfth earl of Derby from 1521, with residences at Lathom House, New Park and Greenhalgh Castle (Lancashire), and Derby House (London). See P&P.
John Fitzjames (1470-1538/9) was chief justice of the King‚Äôs Bench from 1525, with residences at Redlynch House (Somerset) and Middle Temple (London). See P&P.
Thomas Manners (1497-1543) was twelfth baron Ros from 1513 and third earl of Rutland from 1525, with residences at Belvoir Castle (Leicestershire) and Holywell (London). See P&P.
Katherine of Aragon (1485-1535/6) was queen of England 1509-1533. See P&P.
Henry Grey (1517-1554) was marquess of Dorset from 1530, with residences at Bradgate and Groby (Leicestershire), and Chewton (Somerset). See P&P.

Henry Courtenay (1498-1538/9) was nineteenth earl of Devon from 1511 and marquess of Exeter from 1525, with residences at Colcombe Castle, Okehampton Castle, Tiverton Castle and Columbjohn House, Exeter (Devon). See P&P.
Edward Stanley (1509-1572) was twelfth earl of Derby from 1521, with residences at Lathom House, New Park and Greenhalgh Castle (Lancashire), and Derby House (London). See P&P.
John Tuchet (1483-1557/8) was eighth baron Audley from 1512. See P&P.
Thomas West (1472-1554) was ninth baron La Warre from 1525, with residences at Offington House and Halnaker House (Sussex). See P&P.
Henry Tudor (1491-1547) was Henry VIII of England from 1509. See P&P.

Charles Brandon (1484-1545) was fourth duke of Suffolk from 1513, with residences at Westhorpe Hall (Suffolk), Suffolk Place (Surrey), and Grimsthorpe Castle and Tattershall Castle (Lincolnshire). See P&P.

This set of accounts covers two years because Walter Baker was mayor both years and he lumped his accounts for the two years together. All three pages of accounts for this year are crossed through. The first folio (66) has an unfinished sum at the bottom, while the second folio of receipts and the folio of payments are never summed. The accounts are followed by a blank folio (67v), which is unusual in these accounts, suggesting that they are incomplete and perhaps draft accounts.

In 1533‚Äì4 Sir Edward Hordes received v s. toward his gown and four other men, presumably the sergeants, received money for their coats (Butler, Book of Fines, vol 1, p 158). It is not certain who 'my lord' was, whom they and the mayor went to welcome at Winchester; it may have been Stephen Gardiner, who became bishop of Winchester in November 1531.

div.p: Henry Tudor (1491-1547) was Henry VIII of England from 1509. See P&P.
Edward Stanley (1509-1572) was twelfth earl of Derby from 1521, with residences at Lathom House, New Park and Greenhalgh Castle (Lancashire), and Derby House (London). See P&P.

The interlineation identifying Brandon as the king's juggler appears to be in the hand of the auditor, whose work can be seen in the sums at the bottom of the page. Thomas Brandon, Henry VIII's juggler, was famous and travelled frequently through the country; for more information on Brandon, see Performance Traditions.

div.p: Henry Fitzroy (1519-1536) was Lord Admiral, first duke of Richmond and fourth duke of Somerset from 1525, with residences at Sheriff Hutton and Pontefract (Yorkshire). See P&P.
Henry Tudor (1491-1547) was Henry VIII of England from 1509. See P&P.

The mayor recorded only five payments in the Book of Fines this year, which are copied from the mayor's accounts (SC5/3/2), which appear to be the rough accounts. In the rough accounts the reward to Brandon is given as 'vj s. vj d.,' but a long horizontal line between the 'v' and 'j' may have been intended to represent the two missing minims in 'viij d.'

row.cell: Item gaue to vj of my lord princes playars yn rewarde

div.p: Edward Tudor (1537-1553 was prince of England 1537-1546/7 and king of England from 1546/7. See P&P.
The reward to the prince's players is one of only five payments the mayor recorded this year.

div.head: f 19 (29 September‚Äì29 September) (Incidental payments and presents)

row.cell: The. xiiij daye of awguste to the prynces pleyers
The. xiiij daye of September to the kynges pleyers at the dolffyne which pleyd nott

div.p: Edward Tudor (1537-1553 was prince of England 1537-1546/7 and king of England from 1546/7. See P&P.
Henry Tudor (1491-1547) was Henry VIII of England from 1509. See P&P.

The 'dolffyne' was an inn on the east side of English Street (now High Street) next to Holy Rood Church. The Dolphin Hotel, a later structure, still stands on the site (Nikolaus Pevsner and David Lloyd, Hampshire and the Isle of Wight, The Buildings of England (Harmondsworth, Mx, 1967; rpt 1979), 546‚Äì7).

div.p: Edward Seymour (1500-1551/2) was eighth earl of Hertford from 1537, with residences at Somerset House (Middlesex) and Wolf Hall (Wiltshire). See P&P.
Robert Radcliffe (1483-1542) was sixth earl of Sussex from 1529, with residence at Attleborough (Norfolk). See P&P.

The mayor made rather more numerous payments this year (half a page worth) than during the 1530s. The mayor's draft accounts for this year survive (SC5/3/3) and contain the rewards to Hartford's minstrels and Sussex's players. They also include a payment to the lord privy seal's minstrels that has been crossed out, no doubt because it belongs to the following year, 1542‚Äì3, which is where it has been entered in the Book of Fines.

The bearward apparently baited his bear at the town bull-ring, where he collected 2s 8d, to which the town officials added 2s 4d to bring his total to 5s.

div.p: Robert Radcliffe (1483-1542) was sixth earl of Sussex from 1529, with residence at Attleborough (Norfolk). See P&P.

John Russell (1485-1554/5) was keeper of the Privy Seal from 1542 and third earl of Bedford from 1549/50, with residences at Bedford House, Exeter (Devon), Chenies (Buckinghamshire) and Russell House (London). See P&P.
William Paulet (1474-1571/2) was first baron of St John from 1538/9, with residences at Basing House and Netley (Hampshire), Chelsea (Middlesex) and Austin Friars (London). See P&P.
The payments are especially numerous this year: covering two full folios. The entry just above that about Lord St John's minstrels is a reward to the messenger who brought the proclamation for war.

div.p: Edward Tudor (1537-1553 was prince of England 1537-1546/7 and king of England from 1546/7. See P&P.

div.head: ff 57‚Äì7v
div.ab: A proclamacion sett furth by the kings maiestie with thas sent of his deryst vnncle Edwarde duke of Somersett Governor of his most royeall personne and of hys Realmes dominions and subiectes protector and and others of his most honorable Counsaill for the inhibicion of playes

fforasmuche as a grete number of those those be common players of Enterludes and playes aswell with in the Cityeplayes of London as ells where with in the realme doo for the most part play suche enterludis as contayne matter tending to sedicion and contempning of Sundrey good orders and Lawes whereapon are growen and dayly are like to growe and ensue muche disquietplayes diuicion tumultes and vprores in this Realme The kinges maiestye by thadvise and consent of hys deryst vnncle Edward duke of Somersett Governor of his person and protector of hys Realmes dominions and Subiectes and the rest of hys priuie Counsall straghtly chargith and commandeith all and every hys maiestis subiectes of whatt soever state ordre or degree they be that from the ixth daye of this present moneth of August vntill the ffeaste of all sayntes next cuming they ne any of them openly or secretly play ne in the Inglishe tongue any kynd of Interlude playe Dialogue or other matter sett forth in forme of playe in any place publique or priuate with in this Realme vppon payn that whoo soever shall playe in Inglishe any such playe Interlude dialogue or other matter shall suffer imprisonement and further punishement at the plesuer of his maiestie

ffor the better execucion wherof hys maiestie by the sayde advise and consent straghtly chargith and commandith all and singuler Maiors Shriffis Baalifes constables hedborowis tything men Iustices of peace and all others his hedd officers in all the partyes throwgh owt the Realme
to geue ordre and speciall heedd that this proclamacion be in all behalfis wen well and truly kept and obserued as they and everie of them tendre his highnes plesuer and wyll avoyed his Indignacion/ Gevin at westminster the vjth of August in the iij yere of the kinges Maiestes Reign/

row.cell: Item. to the Quenes Iester Mr Renerd

Item. ij mens chargys to WilltonnWilltonn: the earl of Pembroke's household at Wilton House, or the town of Wilton, both near Salisbury to fett disgysinge apparrell and to tychefylde for the horsemen in the Maye
Item. for thinges fett at Mr GoddardesMr Goddardes: likely Thomas Goddard, mayor in 1550‚Äì1 for the gowne. of Satten made for the May

Item for vij yardes of grene Satten A bridgis at ij s. vj d. the yarde for the Mayes gowne remaynynge in the handes of Mr VincenteMr Vincente: probably George Vincent, who had been steward, bailiff, and sheriff, and would become mayor in 1557‚Äì8

div.p: Mary Tudor (1515/16-1558) was queen of England from 1553. See P&P.

The third entry contains an apparently otiose vertical line between 'Satten' and 'made.' The fourth entry appears to end at 'gowne' with the final line added, with a bracket at the right extending down to the end just above the horizontal line following 'Vincente.' Only a single amount is entered for these lines.

For 'fett' in the second and third entries (that is, 'fetch' and 'fetched' respectively), Burch reads 'sett' (p 30), but the ligature from 's' to 'e' in this hand usually comes from the top right hand end (the right end of the curving top of the stroke), whereas this ligature comes from the middle of the vertical stroke, as if the crossing of the 'f'; 'f' and 's' are otherwise indistinguishable in this hand.

row.cell: Item. more paide the x daye of Ianuarij vnto the players that pleyde at maister mayors denner in the towne hall Summa

div.p: Since no patron is named, these players may have been musicians or perhaps local amateur players.

row.cell: Item more in Reward to my lord valossys berewardes

div.p: 'my lord valossys' cannot be definitely identified, but 'valossys' is most likely a spelling for 'Valois' suggesting that the bearward's patron was a member of the French ruling family.

row.cell: Item. paid the v daye of Iuly to the eyrle of oxfordes players the some of
Item. paid the xviij daye of augoste for a gallon wine geven to sir hew pallatt
Item. paid the same daye at the admiralles courte at hamble for bredd bere wine
Item. paid the vj daye of september to sir Ihon foscuisfoscuis: ie, Fortescue's players that plaid before master mayre at the towne hayle
Item. paid the xiij daye of dissember to my Lorde of arronndelles players that plaid be fore master mayre and his bretherbrether: for brethern; abbreviation mark missing
Item. paid the iiij daye of october to my Lorde RoberttRobertt: with otiose es; abbreviation mark after final 't' t doudleyes players
Item. paid the xxiiij daye of october to the eyrle of oxfordes players the some of
Item. paid the xvij daye of november to the duches of suffokes players the some

div.p: John de Vere (1516-1562) was sixteenth earl of Oxford from 1539, with residence at Hedingham Castle (Essex). See P&P.
Sir John Fortescue (1533-1607) was Master of the Queen‚Äôs Wardrobe from 1559, with residences at Welford (Berkshire), Salden (Buckinghamshire) and Holborn (Middlesex). See P&P.
Henry Fitz Alan (1512-1579/80) was twenty-fourth earl of Arundel from 1543, with residences at Arundel Castle (Surrey) and Arundel House (London). See P&P.

Robert Dudley (1532-1588) became Lord Robert Dudley in 1551 and was fourteenth earl of Leicester from 1564, with residences at Kenilworth Castle (Warwickshire), Kew House (Surrey), Leicester House and Durham Place (London). See P&P.
Katherine Willoughby (1518/19-1580) was duchess of Suffolk from 1533, with residences at Westhorpe (Suffolk), Grimsthorpe and Tattershall Castle (Lincolnshire). See P&P.

row.cell: Item so miche gyven to the singers players & Morris daunsers on Maye daye
Item. paid to the rlerle: for erle; letter obscured by smudge of Warwyckes players the xixth daye of Marche
Item. paid the xvth daye of Iune to the Quenes maiesties players

div.p: Ambrose Dudley (1528-1589/90) was earl of Warwick from 1561, with residences at North Hall (Hertfordshire) and Warwick Castle (Warwickshire). See P&P.
Elizabeth Tudor (1533-1602/3) was queen of England from 1558. See P&P.

row.cell: Item paid the xxviijth daye of September to the Quenes Iuggeler
Item paid to George Tayler one of the Quenes messengers for bringing of wryttes
Item paid the xxvth of October to the erle of warwickes players
Item paid the iiijth daye of November to my L L: for Lord; no abbreviation mark in MS Strange his players

div.p: Elizabeth Tudor (1533-1602/3) was queen of England from 1558. See P&P.
Ambrose Dudley (1528-1589/90) was earl of Warwick from 1561, with residences at North Hall (Hertfordshire) and Warwick Castle (Warwickshire). See P&P.

Henry Stanley (1531-1593) was Lord Strange from 1531 and the thirteenth earl of Derby from 1572, with residences at Lathom House and Greenhalgh Castle (Lancashire), Stanley House (Cheshire), Gaddesden Magna (Hertfordshire) and Derby House (Middlesex). See P&P.

In the Gloucester chamberlains' accounts for this same year, the queen's juggler is identified as one 'Stanweye' (Audrey Douglas and Peter Greenfield (eds), Cumberland / Westmorland / Gloucestershire, REED (Toronto, 1986), 299).

row.cell: Item Rewarde to Mr Leythe Scholemaster for his play

div.p: The mayor and council were the governors of Southampton's Free Grammar School, which they founded in 1553 (Butler, Book of Fines, vol 2, pp xxi, 24). Nothing else is known of 'Mr Leythe,' who is not included in the list of headmasters in the school's history (Russell, King Edward VI School, p 350). This year's payments include many gifts: to the earl of Southampton and his mother, to Lord Pembroke, to the lord (bishop?) of Winchester, and to Lord and Lady Lumley (all on f 119v).

row.cell: Item. payd the x daye of marche to grigori steuen on of the quenes mesengers for bringen of other wryts
Item. payd the sam daye to me lorde the Erell of woseters pleres
Item. payd the laste daye of maye to the quenes grasious plears
Item. payd the xij daye of agost to me lord Erell of darbes berodes

div.p: William Somerset (1527-1588/9) was eighth earl of Worcester from 1549, with residences at Chepstow Castle and Raglan Castle (Monmouthshire), Hackney and St John‚Äôs House (Middlesex). See P&P.
Elizabeth Tudor (1533-1602/3) was queen of England from 1558. See P&P.

Henry Stanley (1531-1593) was Lord Strange from 1531 and the thirteenth earl of Derby from 1572, with residences at Lathom House and Greenhalgh Castle (Lancashire), Stanley House (Cheshire), Gaddesden Magna (Hertfordshire) and Derby House (Middlesex). See P&P.

The content of the rewards this year is rather broader, including gifts of wine to Lord Lumley and the bishop of Winchester and horse meat for the city recorder, in addition to messengers and players.

div.head: f 125v (29 September‚Äì29 September)
div.ab:
paymentes by the saide mayorthe saide mayor: John Crooke, mayor in 1568‚Äì9 and 1584‚Äì5
when the Quens maiesty was here.

row.cell: Imprimis presented to the quens maiesty in the forsaide purse the ixth of september
Item geuen to the clarke of the markett for a rewarde
Item to the quens harwardeharwarde: for barwarde
Item to her sargeante of the armes
Item payed the marshall for a proclimacion
Item payed the marshall for his fees
Item payed to the clarke of the marketes cryer
Item payed to the skylorsskylors: meaning uncertain; the second letter is a 'k,' but the most likely explanation is an error for 'a' ‚Äì thus 'saylors,' ie, 'sailors'
Item payed to the drome and flute of portismothe
Item to the yemen of the mayell
Item to the yemen of the bottells
Item payed Peter glasier for his drome and flute
Item payed the Quens maiestis porters

div.p: Elizabeth Tudor (1533-1602/3) was queen of England from 1558. See P&P.

The remaining payments are of a general nature and not related to the queen's visit, although no indication appears in the manuscript at the end of the items for the queen's visit. The mayor's rough accounts (SC5/3/6) survive for this year and give the same set of payments, differing only in the mayor's highly idiosyncratic spelling. 'Peter glasier' was also known as Peter Breme, and he was paid for glazing and painting of civic buildings, as well as for playing his drum and flute for musters. In 1583 he received cloth for his livery, along with other civic officials.

row.cell: Item payed my Lorde of Lessitors players the seconde tyme they played when that sir henry wallope and his Ladie was there
Item payed to George gylbert Lorde of the bulryng xxs

div.p: Robert Dudley (1532-1588) became Lord Robert Dudley in 1551 and was fourteenth earl of Leicester from 1564, with residences at Kenilworth Castle (Warwickshire), Kew House (Surrey), Leicester House and Durham Place (London). See P&P.
Sir Henry Wallop (c 1531‚Äì99) was a leader of the Protestant gentry in Hampshire; his estate was at Farleigh Wallop near Basingstoke.

Although 'Item' is written out in full, an otise abbreviation mark of a horizontal line consistently appears over it in the hand of this year's accounts. The heading gives the regnal years of these accounts as 12‚Äì13 Elizabeth, but the following year's accounts are also so headed, and internal dates in the next set of accounts suggest that this one is in fact for 11‚Äì12 Elizabeth, 1569‚Äì70.

Butler (Book of Fines, vol 2, p 84) transcribes the second entry on this folio thus: 'Item the xth of maye payed unto mr Shuxborowe fare Lace vjd. for nayles iijd. to sette uppe the Revills of the Kinge in the Audict howsse ixd.' Such a record would certainly merit inclusion in this edition. However, the word Butler has transcribed as 'Revills' seems clearly to instead be 'Roulls,' which would also make more sense in the context of the Audit House.

row.cell: Item for mony gathered by the wives at hocketide 1568 remayning in thandes of mr buck
Item for mony gathered by the wives at hocketide 1569 remayning in mr buckes handes

div.p: 'mr buck,' one of the churchwardens for this year, may be Thomas Bucke, a merchant of St Lawrence's parish, who became a burgess of Southampton in 1560‚Äì1 (Butler, Book of Fines, vol 2, p 38).

row.cell: Item the xiijth of Ianuarye gave the berewood
Item the xxviijth of Ianuarie payed to the bereward
Item the ixth of september gave my lorde Sand Wayeslorde Sand Wayes: William, Baron Sandys of the Vyne (d. 1632); the Vyne was a manor in northern Hampshire, near Basingstoke berewood

div.p: William Sandys (1555-1623) was third baron Sandys from 1559, with residence at The Vyne (Hampshire). See P&P.

Both this year's and the previous year's accounts are dated 12‚Äì13 Elizabeth. However, the last two leaves of the previous year's accounts are labelled '1570' at the top of each leaf, while these accounts are headed '1571' at the top of each leaf, so these accounts seem likely to be the ones for 1570‚Äì1. In fact, the mistake was made a few years earlier, when the regnal years given in the headings suddenly skip from 8‚Äì9 Elizabeth to 10‚Äì11 Elizabeth. After the correction made in this year's heading, the regnal years no longer conflict with dates given within the accounts.

row.cell: Item geven to a berwarde for pastyme shewyd
Item more geven to a berward for a Rewarde

div.p: Entries in this year's accounts are only rarely dated and the order may not be chronological.

row.cell: Item the xvijth daye of November for j Barrell of double beare and Cakes for the men that made pastime in the streate for the Quene

Item the xviijth daye of Nobember to Sir Harrye RadecliffeSir Harrye Radecliffe: Sir Henry Radcliffe (1533‚Äì93, 9th earl of Sussex) and Sir Harry Seamer j galand of Claret wine j pottell of secke price
Item the xxvijth daye of November to the Erle of Sussex Players by Mr Nicholas Caplin and Mr Stavelies order paied

div.p: Thomas Radcliffe (1526-1583) was eighth earl of Sussex from 1556/7 and lord chamberlain of the household from 1572, with residences at Woodham Walther and New Hall (Essex) and Bermondsey House (Surrey). See P&P.

There is no other mention of the queen's visit in this year's accounts, though of course the missing steward's accounts might have included expenses on that occasion. Sir Henry Radcliffe was the younger brother of Thomas Radcliffe (1526‚Äì83), 8th earl of Sussex; Henry Radcliffe became earl of Sussex on his brother's death in 1583. Radcliffe was at this time MP for Portsmouth, as well as warden and captain of that town, so Southampton had good reason to seek his favour, and that of his brother, Thomas, the earl of Sussex, who had recently been named lord chamberlain by Queen Elizabeth.

Sir Henry Seymour (1503‚Äì78) was the brother of Jane Seymour and uncle to Edward VI; he had a residence at Winchester and had been sheriff of the county in 1568‚Äì9. The Capelin and Staveley families were both prominent in Southampton in this period, with multiple mayors coming from each family. Nicholas Capelin was never mayor, however, so it is not clear why he and one of the Staveleys are commanding this payment.

row.cell: Item paid to the Earle of Leycetors players

div.p: Robert Dudley (1532-1588) became Lord Robert Dudley in 1551 and was fourteenth earl of Leicester from 1564, with residences at Kenilworth Castle (Warwickshire), Kew House (Surrey), Leicester House and Durham Place (London). See P&P.

The dating by regnal years again gets a year out of step with the heading of the 1573‚Äì4 accounts as 16‚Äì17 Elizabeth (f 147), following the accounts for 14‚Äì15 Elizabeth ‚Äì there is no set of accounts headed 15‚Äì16 Elizabeth. The error becomes clear with the accounts for 1576‚Äì7, which are headed 19‚Äì20 Elizabeth (which would be 1577‚Äì8) but are twice dated internally to 1577 before Michaelmas.

row.cell: Item paid to Mr Adrian for his charges and pains in his tragedie, by consent
Item by consent giuen to my Lorde comptons plaiers for their Pains

div.p: Henry Compton (1537/8-1589) was first Baron Compton from 1572, with residences at Compton Wynyates (Warwickshire) and Tottenham (Middlesex). See P&P.

'Item' of the Adrian entry is written larger and bolder, as all first entries are on pages in this year's hand. This entry comes immediately after what appear to be weekly accountings of expenses for repairs to town plumbing, the last headed 19 February, and two entries before a payment for attorney's fees made on 28 February.

'Mr Adrian' is likely to have been Adrian (or Hadrian) Saravia, who was headmaster of Southampton's Free Grammar School from 1572 to 1578. Saravia was born in the Netherlands around 1532 and in early adulthood was important in the Dutch Calvinist reformed church. He came to Southampton in the 1570s, returned to the continent from 1578 to 1588, then returned to England where he held a number of offices in the Anglican Church, and worked to reconcile Anglican episcopal hierarchy with Calvinism. He played a role in Anglo-Dutch relations throughout his life (Willem Nijenhuis, Adrianus Saravia (c.1532‚Äì1613), Dutch Calvinist, First Reformed Defender of the English Episcopal Church Order on the Basis of the ius divinum, Studies in the History of Christian Thought 21 (Leiden, 1980), 1‚Äì40. See also Russell, King Edward VI School, pp 34‚Äì49). Thus, the tragedy would have been performed by the boys of the school, perhaps with the mayor and his brethren in the audience, but not necessarily, as the corporation was responsible for the school's expenses.

The dating of these accounts by regnal years gets a year out of step with the heading of the 1573‚Äì4 accounts as 16‚Äì17 Elizabeth (f 147), following the accounts for 14‚Äì15 Elizabeth: there is no set of accounts headed 15‚Äì16 Elizabeth. The error becomes clear with the accounts for 1576‚Äì7, which are headed 19‚Äì20 Elizabeth (which would be 1577‚Äì8) but are twice dated internally to 1577 before Michaelmas.

row.cell: Item paid by consent to xj Players being the Lorde of Bathes Players the first of maie 1577
Item paid by consent to my Lord Delawarres Plaiers being tenne of them the vjth of may
Item paid by consent to the Earle of worceter his players the 14 of Iune being x of them
Item paide the 24th of Iune to sixe of my Lorde Clintons Players
Item paid to sixe of R Sir Richard bartlattes Players 27 of Iune 6 of them
Item paid to my Lorde stranges servantes v young men vauters & Iumpers comonlie called Iumpers or Tumblers the 29 of Iune
Item paid to Tenne Players of my Lorde Staffordes the 8th of Iuly
Paid to my Lorde of Leycesters plaiers xij of them the xxijth of September 1577

div.p: William Bourchier (1557-1623) was fourth earl of Bath from 1560/1, with residences at Bampton Castle and Tawstock Court (Devon). See P&P.
William West (1519-1595) was tenth baron De La Warr from 1569/70, with residences at Wherwell (Hampshire) and Offington House (Sussex). See P&P.
William Somerset (1527-1588/9) was eighth earl of Worcester from 1549, with residences at Chepstow Castle and Raglan Castle (Monmouthshire), Hackney and St John‚Äôs House (Middlesex). See P&P.
Henry Clinton (1540-1616) was Baron Clinton from 1572 and earl of Lincoln from 1584/5, with residence at Tattershall (Lincolnshire). See P&P.
Richard Berkeley (1531-1605) was knighted in 1574, with residence at Stoke House (Gloucestershire). See P&P.

Henry Stanley (1531-1593) was Lord Strange from 1531 and the thirteenth earl of Derby from 1572, with residences at Lathom House and Greenhalgh Castle (Lancashire), Stanley House (Cheshire), Gaddesden Magna (Hertfordshire) and Derby House (Middlesex). See P&P.
Edward Stafford (1535/6-1603) was twelfth Baron Stafford from 1565/6, with residences at Stafford Castle (Staffordshire) and Caus Castle (Shropshire). See P&P.

Robert Dudley (1532-1588) became Lord Robert Dudley in 1551 and was fourteenth earl of Leicester from 1564, with residences at Kenilworth Castle (Warwickshire), Kew House (Surrey), Leicester House and Durham Place (London). See P&P.

The accounts for this year are both very extensive and very detailed. Although individual entries are clearly dated to 1576‚Äì7, the heading gives regnal years of 19‚Äì20 Elizabeth, which would translate to 1577‚Äì8. (The dating by regnal years again gets a year out of step with the heading of the 1573‚Äì4 accounts as 16‚Äì17 Elizabeth (f 147), following the accounts for 14‚Äì15 Elizabeth ‚Äì there is no set of accounts headed 15‚Äì16 Elizabeth. The error becomes clear with the accounts for 1576‚Äì7, which are headed 19‚Äì20 Elizabeth (which would be 1577‚Äì8) but are twice dated internally to 1577 before Michaelmas.)

row.cell: Item the xxth of ffebruarie gaue to Sir Mathew Arondells men for shewing pastime with their beares & plaing that nighte with their poppettes
The xxiijth daie of ffebruarie gaue to the Waites of Salisburie the Summe of
Item the xixth daie of Marche gaue to my Lorde Dudleys v Musicioners summe
Item the vth of Aprill gaue to two ffrench boyes that were Tumblers which shewed pastime
Item the laste of Maye gaue to the waites of Warwicke in monie
Item the vijth of August gaue to my Lorde of LeicesoresLeicesores: for Leicestores men
Item the tenth of September gaue to the Waites of bristowe

div.p: Sir Matthew Arundell (c. 1532-1598) was a member of Parliament for Shaftesbury and Brecknockshire.
Edward Sutton (1515-1586) was fourth Baron Dudley from 1553, with residence at Dudley Castle (Shropshire). See P&P.

Robert Dudley (1532-1588) became Lord Robert Dudley in 1551 and was fourteenth earl of Leicester from 1564, with residences at Kenilworth Castle (Warwickshire), Kew House (Surrey), Leicester House and Durham Place (London). See P&P.

The low amount (2s) of the payment to 'my Lorde of Leicesores men' (f 171v) suggests that these were not Leicester's players, who were paid 20s two years earlier, but they could possibly have been musicians.

row.cell: Itam. gave the erell of darbyes players
Itam. gave my lord mongoes players the second day of februarij
Itam. gave vnto the quenes bererd Summa

div.p: Henry Stanley (1531-1593) was Lord Strange from 1531 and the thirteenth earl of Derby from 1572, with residences at Lathom House and Greenhalgh Castle (Lancashire), Stanley House (Cheshire), Gaddesden Magna (Hertfordshire) and Derby House (Middlesex). See P&P.
James Blount (1433-1581) was sixth Baron Mountjoy from 1544, residences at Hooke Court (Dorset), Apehthorpe (Northamptonshire), and Silver Street (London). See P&P.
Elizabeth Tudor (1533-1602/3) was queen of England from 1558. See P&P.

row.cell: Item Receued of henrie the Minstrell for his ffredome of the keping of the waightes

div.p: Henry the minstrel paid for his freedom between 12 and 28 January 1579/80.

div.head: f 5v (29 September‚Äì29 September)
div.ab: Lyveries for officers as followeth
the ixth day of December 15801580: underlined in MS

div.p: This list of the liveries given appears on a separate page at the end of the accounts and was not copied into the Book of Fines. In the payments is an entry concerning the total cost of the liveries: 'paid to Mr. Carewe of London draper for xlvj yeardes quarter of broad Cloth at viij s. the yeard for Lyueries for the townes officers ‚Äì xviij li. x s.' (f 3).

row.cell: Item paid for paper and Candells at Mr Caliuers playe
Item geven to my Lord Stafordes players
Item geven to my Lord Morleys players
Item geven to the Quenes berrerd
Item geven to my Lorde of Penbrokes musysionns
Geven to Sir frauncis drakes musicions
Item geven to the trumpheters of the gallion Lecester
Item paid to preston drom player
Item geven to the trumpheters of Sir frauncis Drake
Item geven to the wayghtes of bristolle
Item geven to the waytes of Chester
Item geven to the Earle of Worchesters players
Item geven to my Lord of Lecesters players
Item geven to my Lorde Chamberlaynes players

div.p: Edward Stafford (1535/6-1603) was twelfth Baron Stafford from 1565/6, with residences at Stafford Castle (Staffordshire) and Caus Castle (Shropshire). See P&P.
Edward Parker (1551-1618) was twelfth Baron Morley from 1577, with residences at Belhouse Manor (Norfolk), Hallingbury Place (Essex) and Hornby Castle (Leicestershire). See P&P.
Elizabeth Tudor (1533-1602/3) was queen of England from 1558. See P&P.
Henry Herbert ( 1538-1600/1) was twenty-first earl of Pembroke from 1569/70, with residences at Cardiff Castle (Glamorgan), Wilton (Wiltshire), and Ludlow Castle (Shropshire). See P&P.
Francis Drake (1539/40-1596) was knighted in 1581, with residences at Plymouth and Buckland Abbey (Devon), The Erber (London). See P&P.
William Somerset (1527-1588/9) was eighth earl of Worcester from 1549, with residences at Chepstow Castle and Raglan Castle (Monmouthshire), Hackney and St John‚Äôs House (Middlesex). See P&P.

Robert Dudley (1532-1588) became Lord Robert Dudley in 1551 and was fourteenth earl of Leicester from 1564, with residences at Kenilworth Castle (Warwickshire), Kew House (Surrey), Leicester House and Durham Place (London). See P&P.

Thomas Radcliffe (1526-1583) was eighth earl of Sussex from 1556/7 and lord chamberlain of the household from 1572, with residences at Woodham Walther and New Hall (Essex) and Bermondsey House (Surrey). See P&P.

Mr Caliver's play (f 181v) was probably a school play like the ones for which the town had rewarded previous masters of the Free Grammar School in 1565‚Äì6 and 1575‚Äì6. Mr Caliver was schoolmaster of the Free Grammar School; on 12 October 1582 'Mr Calvert Scholemaster' was paid ¬£5 16s 8d for wages due the preceding Michaelmas (f 184v). In the 1586‚Äì7 accounts he is identified as 'mr calverd preacher' (f 204v).

row.cell: Item paid to William fox Stewarde for to geve vnto my Lord of Derbeys players
Item geven to thearle of Oxford players

div.p: Henry Stanley (1531-1593) was Lord Strange from 1531 and the thirteenth earl of Derby from 1572, with residences at Lathom House and Greenhalgh Castle (Lancashire), Stanley House (Cheshire), Gaddesden Magna (Hertfordshire) and Derby House (Middlesex). See P&P.

Edward de Vere (1550-1604) was seventeenth earl of Oxford from 1562, with residences at Wivenhoe and Plaistow House (Essex), Stoke Newington (Middlesex), The Savoy and Fisher‚Äôs Folly (London). See P&P.

row.cell: Given my lorde of Oxfordes players

div.head: f 188v
div.ab: Laide out for Liveries for the officers
this yeare as ffolloweth in Anno 1583
To Peter breame j yearde 2 quarter 1/2
To henrye Myles j yeard 2 quarter
To thomas Williams j yeard 2 quarter 1/2
To thomas Breame j yeard 2 quarter
To Symon Reston j yard 2 quarter
To Henry helliar j yeard q 3 quarter

row.cell: Soe the saide Lieveries dothe amount vnto 51 yardes 1/2 quarter at 8s 8d the yeard amountes to
xxij li. iij s. j d.

div.p: Edward de Vere (1550-1604) was seventeenth earl of Oxford from 1562, with residences at Wivenhoe and Plaistow House (Essex), Stoke Newington (Middlesex), The Savoy and Fisher‚Äôs Folly (London). See P&P.
Elizabeth Tudor (1533-1602/3) was queen of England from 1558. See P&P.

All these entries are linked by a bracket on the right, to the right of which the total ('Lj yeardes 1/2 quarter') is written. 'henrye Myles' is likely the 'henrie the Minstrell' who was given his freedom in 1579‚Äì80 for 'keping of the waightes.' The names that immediately follow Myles' and receive the same amount of cloth (Thomas Williams, Thomas Breame, and Simon Reston) may be those of other civic musicians. 'Peter breame' was a glasier who played the drum and flute for musters, as the accounts for 1568‚Äì9 indicate (f 126, and see Butler, Book of Fines, vol 3, p xxxviii). Henry Helliar was also paid for solder for the gutters of the west hall (f 188).

row.cell: paide to the quenes Bearwarde being her with a lyon & a porpintyne & poppettes
More geuen to my Lord of Sussex players the 5th of Marche
Paide the Lord of Essex players the 23th of March 85

div.p: Elizabeth Tudor (1533-1602/3) was queen of England from 1558. See P&P.
Henry Radcliffe (1533-1593) was ninth earl of Sussex from 1583, with residences at New Hall (Essex) and Bermondsey House (Surrey). See P&P.
Robert Devereux (1565-1600/1) was nineteenth earl of Essex from 1576, with residences at Chartley (Staffordshire), Lamphey Court (Pembrokeshire), Essex House and York House (London). See P&P.

As the entry concerning Essex's players (f 197v) indicates, the regnal years given in the headings of the accounts are still one year out, as 28‚Äì9 Elizabeth would be 1586‚Äì7. The '23th of March 85' is of course 23 March 1586 by modern reckoning, as the new year number was not used until Lady Day (25 March). The entry for the queen's bearward (f 197) appears two entries above one for 4 December and four above one for 3 January, so it probably belongs to the autumn of 1585.

row.cell: paid to my lorde of Sussex players
paid my lorde of Lecesters players
Giuen to my lord Admirall players
Giuen the Quenes Maiesties players the 25th of Iulie 15871587: underlined in MS
Giuen to the waytes of bathe
Giuen to them that shewed the toyes in the hall as leeke to vices of a Clocke

div.p: Henry Radcliffe (1533-1593) was ninth earl of Sussex from 1583, with residences at New Hall (Essex) and Bermondsey House (Surrey). See P&P.

Robert Dudley (1532-1588) became Lord Robert Dudley in 1551 and was fourteenth earl of Leicester from 1564, with residences at Kenilworth Castle (Warwickshire), Kew House (Surrey), Leicester House and Durham Place (London). See P&P.
Charles Howard (1536-1624) was Lord High Admiral 1585-1618-19 and tenth earl of Nottingham from 1597, with residence at Effingham (Surrey). See P&P.
Gyles Brydges (1548-1593/4) was third Baron Chandos from 1572/3, with residence at Sudeley Castle (Gloucestershire). See P&P.
Elizabeth Tudor (1533-1602/3) was queen of England from 1558. See P&P.

This is the second year headed 28‚Äì9 Elizabeth, correctly here. Many dates were given in this set of accounts, suggesting some care in ordering them chronologically. Four entries before the payment to Sussex's players (f 204v) is an entry dated 24 December 1586, while the entry immediately after the Leicester entry is dated 23 March. The entry preceding the one for the lord admiral's players (f 205) is dated 15 May, but no dates follow it on the rest of the page.

row.cell: Giuen to my lord of Sussex players

cell.del: Giuen my lorde of Sussex pleyers

div.p: Henry Radcliffe (1533-1593) was ninth earl of Sussex from 1583, with residences at New Hall (Essex) and Bermondsey House (Surrey). See P&P.

div.head: f 154
div.ab: The xxvjth daye of marche anno domini 1587 was allso put in to the coffer foresaid these obligacons following viz
Item a prentis Indentur wherin a poor boye namid William forde is bounde prentice for xij yeres to henry mylls mynstrell/

div.p: Only the first two digits of the folio number are visible at the upper right corner, which is frayed.
All the obligations listed here (five of them) involve the property and/or upbringing of poor children. For details on Mylls, see Merson, Third Book of Remembrance, vol 3, p 46 and note.

row.cell: paid on Shroue sunday to the Queenes maiestie & the Earle of Sussex players
payed to the Lord Beauchampes players
The 29 of Iune paid to Mr Dutton fore the Queenes players

div.p: Elizabeth Tudor (1533-1602/3) was queen of England from 1558. See P&P.
Henry Radcliffe (1533-1593) was ninth earl of Sussex from 1583, with residences at New Hall (Essex) and Bermondsey House (Surrey). See P&P.
Edward Seymour (1561-1612) was Lord Beauchamp from 1561. See P&P.

The 'Queenes ma{ies}tie & the Earle of Sussex players' (f 225) was a single troupe. The Queen's players seems to have split about this time, with one of the groups amalgamating with the Earl of Sussex's players. The troupe was rewarded under both names at Gloucester, Bristol and Coventry in 1590-1591, as well as at Southampton. 'Mr Dutton' (f 226v) would have been one of the Dutton brothers, John and Laurence, leaders of the Queen's players at this time (Kathman, Index of English Drama). On 27 June the town copied their licence from the master of the revels into the civic record known as Knaplocke's Book (SC2/6/5). The similar licence for Lord Beauchamp's players had been copied on 25 March.

row.cell: Receued by Mr Studley of Mr Bushe gentleman for hurting one of ye players
the 26 of Ianuary geven in reward to the weightes of Southwark

div.head: f 237 (Given to sundry companies of players)

row.cell: Item geuen in reward the 11 of November to the Earle of Worcesters players
Item geuen in reward the 5 of may vnto my Lord Morleys players
Item geuen in reward to the Lord Staffordes players
Item geuen in reward to the Lord of hertfordes players
Item geuen in reward the third of August to her maiesties players
Item the 2 of september to the Lord Staffordes players

div.p: William Somerset (1527-1588/9) was eighth earl of Worcester from 1549, with residences at Chepstow Castle and Raglan Castle (Monmouthshire), Hackney and St John‚Äôs House (Middlesex). See P&P.
Edward Parker (1551-1618) was twelfth Baron Morley from 1577, with residences at Belhouse Manor (Norfolk), Hallingbury Place (Essex) and Hornby Castle (Leicestershire). See P&P.
Edward Stafford (1535/6-1603) was twelfth Baron Stafford from 1565/6, with residences at Stafford Castle (Staffordshire) and Caus Castle (Shropshire). See P&P.
Edward Seymour (1539-1621) was ninth earl of Hertford from 1558/9-1621, with residences at Wolf Hall (Wiltshire), Elvetham (Hampshire), Somerset House and Hertford House (London). See P&P.
Elizabeth Tudor (1533-1602/3) was queen of England from 1558. See P&P.

'Mr Studley' (f 230) is the merchant and former mayor Andrew Studeley (Butler, Book of Fines, vol 3, p 227). The gentleman named 'Mr Bushe' appears only this once in the Book of Fines, so it is likely he was a visitor to the town.

The receipt from Mr Bushe (f 230) appears between entries for Easter Monday and Easter Tuesday. These amounts occur at the very end of the receipts, which had gotten to 23 September before these few entries. None of the named companies are specifically recorded as coming at Easter, which occurred on 26 March 1592.

The Reste for the cliringe of this Acompte Was all vnto IacksoneIacksone: Richard Jackson, under steward this year; brother of John Jackson, mayor the previous year (Butler, Book of Fines, vol 3, p 225) steward at his goinge to sarum with mr Knyghtemr Knyghte: former mayor John Knight (Butler, Book of Fines, vol 3, p 226) & mr goddardemr goddarde: former mayor Richard Goddard (Butler, Book of Fines, vol 3, p 224) about the Comision betwene b.sse & the town 9 . 14 . 3 d. with 16 d. ab.hi: Somme iiij xx xviij li. ix s. ij d.

div.p: Elizabeth Tudor (1533-1602/3) was queen of England from 1558. See P&P.
Charles Howard (1536-1624) was Lord High Admiral 1585-1618-19 and tenth earl of Nottingham from 1597, with residence at Effingham (Surrey). See P&P.

The whole of f 133 appears to relate to the queen's visit to Southampton on progress. It contains many payments as gifts to members of her entourage, including her footmen, grooms of the chamber, the king of arms, the black guard. The writing is rather sloppy, suggesting that this is a rough account to be copied into the mayor's accounts, or perhaps the missing steward's accounts for this year.

div.head: f 15v

ab.foreign: Vicesimo quinto die mensis Marcij Anno domini 1591 Vicesimo ‚Ä¶ 1591: 'On the 25th day of the month of March, year of the lord 1591'

div.ab:
To all iustices of the peace Mayors Sheriffes bailiffes constables and all other her maiestes officers & ministers to whome it apperteineth greeting Know ye that I Edmund Tillney Esquire Master of the quenes maiestes office of the revells by vertue of her highnes lettres patentes vnder the great seale of England vnto me graunted Haue licensed appointed & authorised & by these presentes do license appointe & authorise the bearers heerof Iohn Muffet Iohn Barnes Thomas Blackmore Iohn Newbould
: approximately 24 characters long attendantes on the right honorable the lord Beachamp & ther company for her maiestes better service to vse set forth and play in any citie towne corporate r ani other place or places within this Realme of England all such stage playes comedies tragedies and other publique shewes whateuer as shalbe sne reformed & allowed vnder the hand writing of me the sayd Edward Tillney and none other Request therefore & desireing you & euery of you to whome these presentes shall come quietly & peaceably to permit & suffer the sayd Iohn Muffet Iohn Barnes Thomas Blackwod Iohn Newbould : approximately 25 characters long and their companie to travell & passe from towne to towne & from place to place to show forth & play such stage playes comedies tragedies & publique shewes as aforesayd without anie your lete intervptions or other impedimentes behaueing themselves quietly & honestly as they ought to doe And further requireing you her maiestes Said officers not to suffer aney whatsoeuer to travell or exercise these qualitie contrarie to the lawes of this realme exept they shalbe licensed so to doe & their plays refourmed and allowed vnder my hand writeing And this present license to endure & continewe for the space of one whole yere next enseng the date herof In witnes &c dated the xiiijth of february in the xxxiijth yere of our souereigne lady Elizabeth &c Ed TillneyEd Tillney: Edmund Tilney, Master of the Revels

div.head: f 23v

ab.foreign: Vicesimo septimo die Iunij Anno 1591Vicesimo ‚Ä¶ 1591: 'On the 27@s\th@s/ day of June, year 1591'

div.ab: To all Iustices of the peace Mayors Shreifes bayliffes Constables and other her maiestes officers and ministers to whome these presentes doth apperteine greeting Know ye that I EdwardEdward: for Edmund Tylney Esquier master of the quenes maiestes office of the revells by vertue of her highnes letters vnder the great seale of England to me graunted haue licensed & authorished and by these presentes do license & authorishe the bearers heerof Laurence Dutton & Iohn Dutton two of her maiestes ordinarye players and the company of children by me appointed vnder their gouernment for her maiestes better service in the time of Chrismas to vse shew forth & play all such playes comedies & tragedies and other publique shewes as shalbe sett downe & alowed vnder the hand writeing of me the sayd Edmund Tillney and none other Desireing therefore & requireing you & every of you to whome these presentes shall come quietly and peaceably to permit & suffer the sayd Lawrence Dutton and Iohn Dutton & their company to travaile from place to place within your precinctes & liberties and to vse shew forth & play all such playes comedies & trageies & other publique shewes as aforesayd without any your lettes trobles or impediamentes behaueing them selves quietly & honestly as they ought to doe And forsomuch as there hath bene great complaintes made of the exesse number of the players that doe traveill from countie to countie som abuseing the name of one noble man and som of an other to the great discredite of that facultie with no lesse troble to the countries where they resort These shalbe also to desire you if any such not haueing license from her maiestes office of the Revells shall happen to wander about from towne to towne that you do not onely reiect them but also binde them to appeare heere at London at her maiestes sayd office by a day provided allwayes that this my present license shall not continew & endure above the space of of one whole yere next ensueing the date herof In witnes &c ‚Ä∏yeven dated the at St Ihones London this xiiijth day of May in the xxxiijth yere of the reigne of our souereigne Ladye Elizabeth &c E Tillney

div.p: Edward Seymour (1561-1612) was Lord Beauchamp from 1561. See P&P.
Elizabeth Tudor (1533-1602/3) was queen of England from 1558. See P&P.

On f 15v Tilney's signature is part of last line of the licence, which comes to the very bottom of the page. The blank spaces appear to have been left to accommodate more names of the acting company. On Tilney and his activities as master of the revels, see W.R. Streitberger, Masters of the Revels and Elizabeth I's Court Theatre (Oxford, 2016). Lord Beauchamp was Edward Seymour (1561‚Äì1612), son of the Edward Seymour who was earl of Hertford and who had angered the queen by marrying Katherine Grey, younger sister of Lady Jane Grey, without Elizabeth's consent in 1560. Hertford was imprisoned until his wife's death in 1568 and spent a long time regaining his standing with the queen. In September of 1591 Hertford hosted Elizabeth on progress at Elvetham, in north-eastern Hampshire, providing elaborate shows for her entertainment. Beauchamp's right to the title was in dispute for most of his life, since his parents' marriage had been declared void and Beauchamp himself illegitimate (ODNB).

There is no way of knowing why the civic authorities in Southampton decided to start copying the players' licences in 1591. One possibility is that the town wanted to be able to refuse permission to play to some visiting companies, and the language of both this licence and the following one makes clear the town's right to deny permission to any companies that could not produce such a licence. Beauchamp's men had only recently gotten into trouble in Norwich, where in June 1590 they were refused permission to play and given 20s to leave town without performing, but according to the mayor's court 'notwithstonding they did sett vpp billes to provoke men to com to their playe and did playe in christechurche' (David Galloway (ed), Norwich, REED (Toronto, Buffalo and London, 1984), 96). John 'Mufford,' as the Norwich record calls him, was jailed for a time for his temerity, which likely means he was the leader of the group. Thomas Blackwood is the only other actor in the group who is mentioned elsewhere, as a member of Worcester's men in 1602 (E.K. Chambers, Elizabethan Stage, vol 2 (Oxford, 1923), 226, 303). Beauchamp's players were never a particularly successful company, but 1590‚Äì1 was one of their busiest years, as they were recorded at Faversham, Lydd, New Romney, Norwich, York, Shrewsbury, and Gloucester, as well as at Southampton (REED, Patrons and Performances, sv 'Seymour, Edward (1561‚Äì1612),' https://library2.utm.utoronto.ca/otra/reed/node/316320#events-naming-patron).

The licence copied on f 23v concerns the Dutton brothers, John and Laurence, who began their acting careers in the early 1570s, joining the earl of Warwick's company in the late 1570s and then shifting to the earl of Oxford's men in 1580 (Kathman, Biographical Index, ). John became a member of the queen's men when the master of the revels assembled that 'all‚Äìstar' company in 1583. By 1591 the queen's men were no longer the pre-eminent company in the land or even at court; Tarlton had died and some of their earlier members had left. Records from around the country suggest that two different companies were travelling in the queen's name in 1591, one led by John Lanham, the other by the Duttons (Scott McMillin and Sally-Beth MacLean, The Queen's Men and their Plays (Cambridge and New York, 1998; rpt 2006), 11‚Äì12, 52‚Äì3, 62). One can easily imagine the mayor at Southampton asking the Duttons to produce their licence and having it copied into the town records, when only a short time before (on Shrove Sunday, 14 February) the town had paid a different group calling themselves the queen's players (see , ff 225, 226v). The earlier visitors were likely Lanham's group, as the Duttons were paid for performing at court in January, February, and March of 1590/1 (W.R. Streitberger, The Masters of the Revels and Elizabeth I's Court Theatre (Oxford, 2016), 278).

row.cell: Item the 18 of October to the Earle of Worcesters players for yt they should not play

div.p: Edward Somerset (1550-1628) was ninth earl of Worcester from 1588/9, with residences at Raglan Castle (Monmouthshire), Worcester House and Hackney (Middlesex). See P&P.
Elizabeth Tudor (1533-1602/3) was queen of England from 1558. See P&P.
Gyles Brydges (1548-1593/4) was third Baron Chandos from 1572/3, with residence at Sudeley Castle (Gloucestershire). See P&P.
William Parker (1574-1622) was fifth Baron Monteagle from 1585, with residences at Hornby Castle (Lancashire), Great Hallingbury (Essex), and Hoxton (Middlesex). See P&P.
Edward Parker (1551-1618) was twelfth Baron Morley from 1577, with residences at Belhouse Manor (Norfolk), Hallingbury Place (Essex) and Hornby Castle (Leicestershire). See P&P.

Ferdinando Stanley (1559-1594) was fourteenth earl of Derby from 1593, with residences at Stanley House (Cheshire); New Park, Lathom House and Greenhalgh Castle (Lancashire) and Derby House (Middlesex). See P&P.
The Montegle entry on f 249 occurs between entries dated 4 March (two above) and 13 March (five below). The Morley and Derby entry on f 249v occurs between entries for 15 and 19 May.

div.head: f 28v
div.ab:
Coppie of a Warraunt vnder the handes of the lords of the
priuie Counsell for players copied the 3d of Iuly
15931593: underlined in MS

Whereas it was thought meete that duringe the tyme of the infection and Continuance of the sicknes in the Cittie of london there shoulde no plaies, or Enterludes be vsd for avoidinge of Assemblies, & Concourse of people in anie vnsuall place appointted near the said Cittie And that the bearers hereof Edward Allen, servaunt to the right honorable the lord high Admirall, William Kempe , Thomas Pope Iohn heminges Augustus Phillippes and George Brian beinge all one Companie, seruauntes to our verie good lorde the Lord Straunge are restrained their exercise of plaienge within the said Cittie, and liberties thereof Yet is not thereby ment but that they shall and maye in regard of the seruice by them donne, and to be donn at the Courte, exercise their qualities of playenge Comedies Tragedies and such like in anie other Citties Townes, and Corporations where the infection is not, soe it be not within seven miles of london, or of the Courte, that they maye bee in the better readines hereafter for her maiestes seruice whensoeuer theie shalbe therevnto called Theis therefore shalbe to Wyll and requier yow that theie maie without your lett, or Contradiction vse theire said exercise, at there most convenient tymes & places, The accustomed tymes of devine seruice prayer excepted, ffrom the Courte at Croydon the vjth daie of Maie 15931593: underlined in MS

seg.note: Iohn Canterbury: John Whitgift (1530/31?‚Äì1604), archbishop of Canterbury
Henry Derby: Henry Stanley (1531‚Äì93), 13th earl of Derby

add.note: Essex: Robert Devereux (1565‚Äì1601), 19th earl of Essex

seg.note: Charles Howard: Charles Howard (1536‚Äì1624), 2nd Baron Howard of Effingham, the lord admiral
Thomas buckhurst: Thomas Sackville (c 1536‚Äì1608), 1st Baron Buckhurst
Iohn wolley: Sir John Wolley (d. 1596), the Latin secretary

div.ab: To all maiars sheriffs Iustices of the Peace Bailiffes Constables, hedboroughes and all other hir Maiestes officers and louinge subiectes to whome it shall apertaineth to euerie of them/.

div.p: Charles Howard (1536-1624) was Lord High Admiral 1585-1618-19 and tenth earl of Nottingham from 1597, with residence at Effingham (Surrey). See P&P.

Lord Strange's men had been forced onto the road when the Rose and other London theatres were shut down due to plague early in 1593. It is likely that they visited Southampton around the third of July, presenting a copy of their warrant from the privy council, which the town had copied into Knaplocke's Book. The accounts in the Book of Fines for this year have been torn out, so unfortunately no reward to Strange's men at this time has survived. Henslowe's Diary indicated that their repertoire while at the Rose in late 1592 and January 1592/3 included The Jew of Malta, Friar Bacon and Friar Bungay, 'harey the vj' (which may or may not have been Shakespeare's), and 'Jeronymo,' no doubt Kyd's Spanish Tragedy (Lawrence Manley and Sally‚ÄìBeth MacLean, Lord Strange's Men and Their Plays (New Haven, 2014), 258‚Äì64, 336‚Äì7).

div.head: f [1]
div.ab: Brother Bunckley as one hopinge of your health, I hartely commend me vnto you Sir Anthony Sherley hath lookt a lonnge time for a chest of vyalls which ar to come downe from London but yet they ar not come and feareth he shal be gone before they come: wherfore my humble sute to you is that you wil send me your chest of vyalls hether that if this fayle we may not be altogether vnprovyded, if his come downe then will I take order that yours shall safly be restored to you agayne also if you wil doe me the favor to lend me your little drum with me to sea, if I live and returne I wil requite al. the newes is hear that the castle of callis holdes out, and my Lord of essex gone with some x thousand to rayse the siege. we only attend a happy wynd, I would it might be my good chance to see you hear ear I goe commend me

div.p: 'Sir Anthony Sherley' is likely Sir Anthony Shirley (1565‚Äì1636?), the second son of Sir Thomas Shirley of Wiston, Sussex. Anthony was knighted by King Henry IV of France in 1593 after serving under the earl of Essex in Normandy. Shirley spent most of his life travelling, wrote a famous account of his visit to Persia, and never returned to England after 1598.

div.head: f 98 (29 September‚Äì29 September)
div.ab: Item To the Musitioner a Coate cloath ‚Ä∏one yearde halfe and halfe quarteron

div.p: This leaf contains a list of customary annual payments to various town officers and their liveries.
Grey Brydges (1578-1621) was fifth Baron Chandos from 1602, with residence at Sudeley Castle (Gloucestershire). See P&P.

div.ab: Right honorable

Although the Spanish AmbassadourSpanish Ambassadour: Juan de Tassis y Acu√±a, first count of Villamediana (d. 1607) doth now since the receipt of your Lordships letter rest pleased, and contented: yet I thought it my duty to let your Lordship vnderstand the apprehensions which hee had formerly conceived, from what grownd, or Intelligence, or whence I cannot learne: but the very same night after hee had written to your Lordship, hee sent for mee, causing mee to sit downe by him, the chamber dore being shut, telling mee directly that his patience endured much at this delay of his Audience, the same first redounding as it did, so highly to the dishonour, and Indignity of the kingking: King Philip III of Spain his Maiestie, secondly, so much to the blemish of his owne reputation, his Idlenes here being not onely turned to a matter of scorne, and scoffing in our Court, but serving to his masters Enemies as a subject of publike laughter, and derision euen in the streetes of Midlebourgh: while in the meane time the Frenche (as hee saide) possessed daily the eares of the king, and Counsaile, triumphing in the Court, and doing their business as they pleased.

To the first I aunswered (as in truthe I Iustly might) that his maiesties greate care had been euen from his first landing at Dover, to haue him honorably vsed in his way toward the Court, as by experience hee had founde; and presently vpon his repaire to Oxford to haue giuen him audience so soone as hee had taken a dayes rest, or two from his Iourney, the altering of which resolution first proceeded from the death of his Chamberlaine: secondly, from his owne request, which hee intreated mee to make to his Maiestie and to the Lordships of the Counsell, that hee might presently bee removed out of Oxford vnto some remote place, where hee might avoyde the daunger of this contagion that began already to take holde of his People; in which his Maiestie was so carefull to giue him satisfaction, that hee presently gaue order for his remooue to Southampton, being one of the healthiest, and sweetest townes in his kingdome, where hee, and his People hath beene by the Magistrates very gently received, and are very fitly, and commodiously lodged.

On Sonday in the afternoone having provided good Musicke, I invited him over to my lodging (the motion first proceeding from himself) where were Ladyes, and Gentlewomen the best of this Towne to accompany him; his Gentlemen and they spente the most parte of the afternoone in dauncing, in which hee himself also bare a parte, being taken out by my Lady LambertLady Lambert: Margaret, wife of Thomas Lambert, mayor in 1599 and MP in 1601, protesting hee had rather indaunger the reputation of his gravity, then of his Courtesye.

On Monday wee had bull-bayting, which hee beheld out of my chamber- windowe, and tooke greate pleasure therein. yesterday in the afternoone there went many Gentlemen, and Gentlewomen to see his howse, whome hee banqueted very roially in the middest whereof his messenger retourned with your Lordships letter, the contents whereof hee presently Imparted vnto mee with much contentment, and is now very busy, and Inquisitiue to knowe in what manner hee shall haue his audience, and how, and ‚Ä∏at what hower when hee shall come, and who shallbe sent vnto him for his conduction.

row.cell: More7. vij li. xvj s. x d. and is so much geven to the Clercke of the markett, to the Trumpetters, to players, and for Conveying of lettres, as appereth by his booke of Casualties, as in debitor folio 9999: cross-reference to corresponding entry on f 98v, numbered '99' in the MS.
vij li. xvj s. x d.

More7. vij li. xvj s. x d. laid out by Mr Chambers viz. geven to the Clercke of the markett, to ye Trumpetters, to players, and for conveying of lettres, as by his booke of Casualties appereth as in Creditor folio 9898: cross-reference to corresponding entry on f 98.
vij li. xvj s. x d.

Thomas32. Gander is due to haue ix s. and is so much paid to Greene the musician in full paiement of his xx s. for kepeing a poore boy, the sonne of one Sopp, as in debitor 126126: cross-reference to corresponding entry on f 125v, numbered '126' in the MS.

div.p: Both entries concerning players on f 98v are preceded by '7.' in the left margin, which is a reference number, rather than a date, as each entry on the page is so numbered. The amount appears to the right of an enclosing bracket, and to the right of the individual amounts is a bracket enclosing the entire page, with the page total to the right of that. The pages are headed 'At the Awditt in November 1606,' and the entries have been taken from the mayor's accounts or 'booke of Casualties' for the previous accounting year, which ran from Michaelmas 1605 to Michaelmas 1606.

row.cell: more151. xxviij s. iij d. paid to Thomas Sherwood goldsmith for 2 Scutcheons for the Towne musicians as in debitor folio 124124: cross-reference to corresponding entry on f 123v, numbered '124' in the MS.
moreScutchions/ 151. xxviij s. iij d. paid to Thomas Sherwood goldsmith, for 2. Scutcheons for the Towne musicians as in Creditor folio 123123: cross-reference to corresponding entry on f 123.

div.p: The actual date these entries were made is November 1607, when mayor's and steward's accounts for the previous accounting year were audited; the payment for the scutcheons was thus made during the previous year.

div.head: f 202 (7 March)
div.ab: AnnaA Warrant from the Queenes Maiestie for her players/. Regina

Anne by the grace of god Queene of England Scottland fraunce and Ierland. To all Iustices of the peace, Maiors M Sheriffes Bayliffes and all other his Maiesties Officers and loveinge subiectes to whome yt shall or maye appertaine greetinge. Know yee that of our speciall grace and favour, Wee are well pleased to authorize vnder our hand and signett the bearers hereof our sworne seruauntes Roberte Lee, Martin Statier and Roger Barfeld with theyr fellowes and Asociates beinge our Commedians vppon theyr humble suite vnto vs for theyr better maintenaunce Yf att anie tim they should haue occasion to travell into anie parte of his Maiesties dominions to playe Tragedyes, historyes, Commedies and pastoralls aswell in and about the Cittye of London, and ‚Ä∏ in all other Cityes vniuersities & townes att all time anie times, (the time of divine seruice onlye excepted) Theis are therefore to will and requier you vppon the sight hereof quiettlye an favourablye (withe your best favours) to permitt and suffer them to vse theyr sayd qualitye within your Iurisdicions without anie of your molestacons or troubles, and also to affourd them your Townehalls and all other such places att anie time haue benn vsed ‚Ä∏by for men of theyr qualitye, That they maye be in the better readines for our seruice when they shalbe therevnto Commaunded, Nott doubtinge butt that our sayd seruauntes shall find the more favour for our sake in your best assistaunce, Wherein you shall doe vnto vs acceptable pleasure. Given at the Court of WhitehallWhitehall: in italic script, the seaventh daye of Marche 16051605: underlined in MS./

div.p: Anne of Denmark (1574-1618/19) was queen of England from 1603. See P&P.

While the warrant was originally written on 7 March 1605/6, the copying of the warrant cannot be dated very exactly: it is preceded by copies of petitions to both Elizabeth and James about how Southampton was suffering from encroachment on its monopoly of the sweet wine trade. None of these, including the last and longest to James, is dated. The item following this warrant, on f 203, is dated 12 November 1606. The dated item closest but before the warrant (f 192v) is dated November 1606 and the one before that (f 191v) 26 October 1606, so it seems likely that the queen's men visited Southampton in the fall, possibly early November, and their warrant was copied at that time.
The outside edge of the leaf has been trimmed in the process of repairing the manuscript, leading to occasional missing letters (here indicated by the diamond brackets).

row.cell: more43. xxv s. geven to players as in debitor folio 126126: cross-reference to corresponding entry on f 125v, numbered '126' in the MS
more32. ix s. paid by Thomas Gander for kepeing a poore boy one Sopp as in Creditor folio 105105: cross reference to corresponding entry on f 105
more43. xxv s. geven to players as in Creditor folio 125125: cross-reference to corresponding entry on f 125

div.p: The entries on f 125v actually made on 7 November 1608, when accounts for previous year were audited.

next 16081608: underlined in MS but now dead in london as s. she sayeth: and the mother of it dyed of the plague the last visitacion in this Towne/ She sayeth that she receaued the childe of Goodye Tompson the musitians wife/ She farther aleadgeth that mr Sherwood Alderman hath in his handes somme howshold stuffe of the said Soppe, for vj s. debt: Whervppon mr sherwood isis: obscured by smudgemr Sherwood requested to cause these thinges to be brought to the howse and he to receaue his monie and the rest of the thinges to be appraised and sould to the vttmost towardes the mayntenence of the childe: which he hath promissed to doe, And hervppon the woeman is bidd goe hoame with the childe, vntill farther conferaunce

div.head: f 41 (22 January 1607/8)
div.ab:
ThisNichollas Yewens daye Nichollas yewens of waltham brought a litle boye namedNichollas ffryce Nichollas ffryce the sonn of Robert ffryce porter deceased to the howse which he hath kept euerThis child
was delivered vpp
to master maior

vppon the xxvth daye
of Marche
1608: by this Nicholas
yewens/ &

Peter heravill
thelder for 3.
yeres in

he is allowed
to Tipple &
to haue vj s. viij d. towarde his apparell. sithence mr neveys Maioraltye at x d. a weeke./ And confesseth himselfe well satisfied and now deliuereth vpp the childe into the Townes hands: Whervuppon the said boye was bounde apprentice in the howse vnto William Greene the Musitian for vntill he shall accomplishe the age of xxiiijor yeares/ when is promissed to haue xx s. with him at thanuntiation next And soe he is contented
Whervppon he was intreated to keep the childe till our Ladye daye next at x d. a weake and betwene this and that a Master shalbe prouiedprouied: for prouided for him

ThisIohn Sopp daye Iohn Sopp the sonn of William Greene Sopp late of this Towne ffeltmaker brought to the howse by Richard hellyer and his wife was deliuered to William greene the musitian to be bounde with him fo till he shall attaine toxxiiij yeresthe yeres of xxiiijer yeares And the said greene is to haue xx s.xx s. in monie with him by our Ladye daye next/ whervnto the said greene consenteth and taketh the childe with him

div.p: On f 37v the two entries concerning musicians are separated by a horizontal line across the folio. Two of the musicians had already been given their livery coats, presumably William Greene and William Tompson, who appeared to be the leaders of the troupe (see the record of 11 December 1607, in which Greene and Tompson are given two silver scutcheons).

Connor writes of the 'scutchins' on f 39: 'The three roses are of course part of the blazon of the town arms; the H and tun are a reference to Hamtun, a form of the name by which the town was still known at this time' (Southampton Mayor's Book, p 110, n 392). The scutcheons still exist among the corporation plate and a photograph of one appears on the cover of Burch, Minstrels and Players.
The entire entry concerning John Sopp on f 39v has been struck though. According to Connor, the plague referred to must have occurred in 1604 (Southampton Mayor's Book, p 111, n 404).

The first entry on f 41 appears to be in error. It seems likely that Greene was never intended to take Fryce as an apprentice but that the scribe mistook the Fryce case for Sopp's, which follows immediately after, and cancelled the erroneous reference to Greene. Of course it is possible that the council did intend to apprentice Fryce to Greene as well and then changed their minds, so that the reference to Greene was cancelled and the note about finding Fryce a master was added before turning to Sopp's case. The marginal note that assigns the boy to Heravill was almost certainly added at a later date.

div.head: f 56 (11 December)
div.ab: Audict=Howse friday the xith of December 16071607: underlined in MS

Wee William greene and William Tompson musicions, seruantes vnto theMr Maior
Mr Cornish
Mr Elliott
Mr Aspten
Mr Neuey
Mr Long
Mr Greene Towne of Southampton Doe hereby acknowledge to haue receued of the Maior Bayliffes and BurgesssBurgesss: for Burgesses of the same Towne five liuerye Cotes of black broad Cloth, whereof two for ourselves, and theother three to be for such our Companie as wee shall thinke fitting to ioyne in Consortshipp with vs; And doe hereby iointlye & seuerallye promise to see the sayd three liueryes att all times foreth coming, to be worne by such others our Companie as in place and name of our now fellowes happening to depart from vs, shall ioyne with vs in the said Consortshipp:

Wee doe alsoe hereby farther acknowledge & confesse to haue this day receued of the sayd Maior, Bayliffes and BurgesssBurgesss: for Burgesses two Scutchins or cognizaunces of siluer impressed with the Townes Armes; Namelye, three RossRoss: for Roses the lettre H; and the forme of a Tonne, waighing together in the whole iiijer ounces and a quarter of an ounce, which wee haue so receued to weare for our badges; And doe hereby likewise iointlye and seuerally promise and bind ourselves our Executors and Administrators vnto the sayd Maior Bayliffes & BurgesssBurgesss: for Burgesses and there Successors in the somme of fortye shillinges sterling to deliuer vpp the sayd two Scutchins or cognizaunces of siluer vnto them or their Successors at all times requiered. Witnes our handes the day and yeare abouesayd/ William Greene

div.p: Connor writes of the 'scutchins' on f 56: 'The three roses are of course part of the blazon of the town arms; the H and tun are a reference to Hamtun, a form of the name by which the town was still known at this time' (Southampton Mayor's Book, p 110, n 392). The scutcheons still exist among the corporation plate and a photograph of one appears on the cover of Burch, Minstrels and Players.

The hand here uses the standard 's' when the mark for 'es' seems called for, as in 'Burgesss' and 'Ross,' where the final 's' is the standard final short 's' and the preceding 's' is the long 's.' The 'es' abbreviation mark is used when not strictly necessary, as in 'Bayliffes.'

Thomas Grymes a younge youthe borne in London keepingeThomas Gryme
dawncer a dawncinge schoole in mr Greenes howse ys ordered and requiered to vse it no more vppon peine of punishment and to settle himselfe into some seruice or depart the Towne which he hath promissedpromissed: 3 minims for mi to performe

div.p: It seems likely that the Mr Greene mentioned here is William Greene, the musician, but Peter and John Greene also appear frequently in the town records at this date and one of the three Greenes was an alderman at the time, his name appearing in the list of the assembled councillors on this date (f 77).
